[[File:Crosby Garrett Helmet on auction at Christies.jpg|300px|thumb|An art auction, as in this one at Christies, is an example of one part of the art market where buyers and sellers of art meet to conduct transactions in the art market]] :{{see also|Art valuation|Art auction}} The art market is represented by a marketplace of buyers and sellers trading in the commodities, services, and works-of-art commonly associated with the various arts. The art market is also concerned with the production of new art which enters the art market. The art market is an example of one type of marketplace, among many different types of markets which occur in economics. In particular, the art market has many similarities with other marketplaces where buyers and sellers meet, as well as significant distinguishing factors indicative of its differences from other types of markets in economics.
==The art market economic model== The [[Economics of the arts and literature#The market for artworks|art market]] operates in an economic model that considers more than [[supply and demand]]: it is a hybrid type of [[prediction market]] where art is bought and sold for values based not only on a work's perceived cultural value, but on both its past monetary value as well as its predicted future value. The market has been described as one where producers don't make work primarily for sale, where buyers often have no idea of the value of what they buy, and where middlemen routinely claim reimbursement for sales of things they have never seen to buyers they have never dealt with.<ref name="platter">Plattner, Stuart, [http://www.stuartplattner.com/AA-ART-Paradox.pdf A Most Ingenious Paradox: The Market for Contemporary Fine Art], ''[[American Anthropologist]]'' 100(2):482-493, 1998.</ref> Moreover, the market is not transparent; private sales data is not systematically available<ref name="Coslor">{{Cite journal|last=Coslor|first=Erica|date=April 2016|title=Transparency in an opaque market: Evaluative frictions between "thick" valuation and "thin" price data in the art market|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0361368216300307|journal=Accounting, Organizations and Society|volume=50|pages=13–26|doi=10.1016/j.aos.2016.03.001}}</ref> and private sales represent about half of market transactions.
===Market size=== Unlike the volumes in the [[securities market]] where millions of people and firms participate in buying and selling financial interests, or the [[Commodity market|commodities market]] where measures of raw or primary products are exchanged using standardized contracts, art market activity largely follows the demands of a more limited array of private collectors, museums, and large corporate interests as the principal market participants.<ref name="microcosm">The art market sees itself as a microcosm: it lists its collectors in the hundreds, as opposed to the securities market which has millions of participants. ''ARTnews'': [http://artnews.com/issues/article.asp?art_id=2536 The Top Ten] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091016003020/http://artnews.com/issues/article.asp?art_id=2536 |date=16 October 2009 }}, [http://artnews.com/issues/article.asp?art_id=2520 The ARTnews 200 Top Collectors] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091016003056/http://artnews.com/issues/article.asp?art_id=2520 |date=16 October 2009 }}. One art writer, however, answered the question: "Do you see the art world as a microcosm of other broader, power communities?" with the following observation: "I'm not sure if it's a microcosm or the shape of things to come. Its manic internationalism...." [http://www.vmagazine.com/2008/11/111208-insider-art/ Insider Art]{{dead link|date=August 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}, ''V Magazine'', 2008-11-12, vmagazine.com. Accessed 20 June 2012.</ref> Corporate collectors, however, can have a disparately large market impact, for instance, ''[[Spear's Wealth Management Survey|Spear's]]'' reported in 2015 that [[British Rail]] began investing in art for its pension fund beginning in 1974 (prior to privatization), spending about £40M or approximately 3% of its funds on art, before selling those assets between 1987–1999.<ref name="britrailspears">Lindsay, Ivan, [http://www.spearswms.com/news/go-figure/#.U4W0eSj8iZQ Go Figure], ''Spear's'', spearswms.com, 21 January 2011; free [https://web.archive.org/web/20140529052940/http://www.spearswms.com/news/go-figure/ archived version]. Accessed 17 November 2015. The article also mentions that British Rail Pension realized an annualized return of 11.3% because of a number of factors particular to the market at the time.</ref> British Rail's efforts realized profits, particularly due to the Impressionist portfolio, but the collection was liquidated because it came to be seen as an illegitimate investment area, particularly as alternative investments became available.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Coslor|first=Erica|last2=Spaenjers|first2=Christophe|date=November 2016|title=Organizational and epistemic change: The growth of the art investment field|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0361368216300782|journal=Accounting, Organizations and Society|volume=55|pages=48–62|doi=10.1016/j.aos.2016.09.003}}</ref> Also, because original artworks are not [[Fungibility|fungible]] like [[stock]]s, they have valuation challenges not similarly affecting securities,<ref name="baumol">Baumol, William J., [http://pchen.ccer.edu.cn/homepage/RecommendPapers/BaumolArts86.pdf Unnatural Value: Or Art Investment as Floating Crap Game] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425235014/http://pchen.ccer.edu.cn/homepage/RecommendPapers/BaumolArts86.pdf |date=25 April 2012 }}, ''The American Economic Review'', 76:2 (May 1986), pp. 10-14, Papers and Proceedings of the Ninety-Eighth Annual Meeting of the American Economic Association,; ''Journal of Arts Management and Law'' (now ''The Journal of Arts Management, Law, and Society''), 15:3, 1985, pp. 47-60. {{DOI|10.1080/07335113.1985.9942162}}.</ref> with dynamics of what Karpik calls singularities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://press.princeton.edu/titles/9215.html|title=Valuing the Unique|website=Princeton University Press|access-date=9 June 2017}}</ref>
Thus, because the art market's participants are far more limited in number than the securities or commodities markets, because artworks are not fungible, and because art valuation relies to a great extent on the advice and enthusiasm of a variety of specialized market analysts, these limitations each in turn dictate the size of the market and increase the risk that some items may be over or undervalued.
===Market timing=== The art market moves in cycles with activity generally peaking in the spring and autumn when the major auction houses traditionally schedule auctions, and results in the market being seasonal rather than ongoing.<ref name="sched">[http://www.artmarket.com/ Art Market Cycles], artmarket.com, retrieved 20 November 2011.</ref> While private sales take place all year, those sales are often not publicized as auctions are and thus do not affect the market until they become known.
Art valuations made for an autumn auction may be unrealistic for the following spring auction season because fortunes in the financial markets during one season can affect the art market in the following season, and equity markets do significantly impact the art market.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Goetzmann|first=William N|last2=Renneboog|first2=Luc|last3=Spaenjers|first3=Christophe|date=May 2011|title=Art and Money|url=http://www.aeaweb.org/articles.php?doi=10.1257/aer.101.3.222|journal=American Economic Review|language=en|volume=101|issue=3|pages=222–226|doi=10.1257/aer.101.3.222|issn=0002-8282}}</ref> Volatility in the financial markets often causes volatility in the art market as happened in the contraction of the art market during the [[2008–2012 global recession|2008-2009 recession]]<ref>For more on the economic background causing the market contraction, see also the [[2008–2009 Keynesian resurgence]].</ref> when sales at [[Sotheby's]], [[Christie's]], and [[Phillips de Pury & Company]] were less than half the previous year: November 2008, $803.3 million compared to November 2007, $1.75 billion; and between 2000 and 2003 when the annual volume of art works sold at auction dropped 36%.<ref name="sched" /><ref name="contraction">Esterow, [http://artnews.com/issues/article.asp?art_id=2642 How to Buy in 2009] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091015210756/http://artnews.com/issues/article.asp?art_id=2642 |date=15 October 2009 }}, ''ARTnews'', March 2009.</ref> In other instances, the art market can fare reasonably well despite volatility in the stock market such as happened from January 1997 through May 2004 when the average quarterly fluctuation in the Artprice Global Index was two to three times smaller than the same statistic for the [[Dow Jones Industrial Average]] and the [[S&P 500]].<ref name="sched" />
As art market participants' fortunes wax and wane in the financial markets, buying power evolves and affects participants' ability to afford highly valued works, resulting in new buyers and sellers entering, leaving, or re-entering the market, and an artwork sold to offset losses in the financial market might be sold for substantially more or substantially less than its last {{H:title|price for which work sold at auctioneer's hammer strike|hammer value|link=no}} at auction.<ref name="gerber">Gerber, Manuel, [http://www.gerberstauffer.com/GerberAFT1108.pdf Primary Art Market Investments - A Safe Haven when All Else Suddenly Correlates?] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131002174957/http://www.gerberstauffer.com/GerberAFT1108.pdf# |date=2013-10-02 }}, Prime Art Management Ltd., published in ''Art Fund Tracker'', Nov. 2008.</ref> In the late 1980s during the stock-market boom, the art market expanded in turn with prices soaring to new heights, and investment firms took a greater interest in the art market and began to study it in-depth.<ref name="campbell">Campbell, [http://i1.exhibit-e.com/collectionofmodernart/39049d22.pdf The Art of Portfolio Diversification]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Maastricht University, March 2004. (art as an asset class)</ref><ref name="goetzmann">Goetzmann, William N., Accounting for Taste: Art and the Financial Markets Over Three Centuries, ''The American Economic Review'', 83(5), Dec. 1993, pp. 1370-1376.</ref> Concurrently, the previously non-transparent art market became more accessible via the increasing availability of indices and online data<ref name="campbellRAJ">Campbell, R.A.J., [http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/Delivery.cfm/SSRN_ID978467_code230208.pdf?abstractid=978467&rulid=6936564&mirid=1 Art as a Financial Investment], Erasmus Univ., Rotterdam, Maastricht Univ., 2007.</ref> although researchers discovered biased price estimates in the auction houses.<ref name="mei">Mei, J. and Moses, M., [http://pages.stern.nyu.edu/~jmei/estimates.pdf Vested Interest and Biased Price Estimates: Evidence from an Auction Market], ''The Journal of Finance'', 60(5), 2005, pp. 2409-2435.</ref>
Art sometimes has transient fashionability that also can affect its value: what sells well for a time may be supplanted in the market by new styles and ideas in short order. For instance, in the spring of 2008 a collector offered over $80 million for Jeff Koons' stainless-steel ''Rabbit'', and yet a year later, of four works in the fall auctions at Christie's and Sotheby's in New York, only two of his pieces sold well and one failed to sell entirely.<ref name="inflatable">[http://www.economist.com/node/14941205 Inflatable investments, The volatile art of Jeff Koons], ''[[The Economist]]'', 28 November 2009.</ref> In 2011, Christie's sold Koons' ''Balloon Flower'' sculpture for $16.9 million.<ref name="koonsballoon">Christie's, [http://www.christies.com/lotfinder/jeff-koons-balloon-flower/5371708/lot/lot_details.aspx?from=searchresults&intObjectID=5371708&sid=e5ce29ac-d2b6-41b6-9092-7aacf3e6974b Auction result, Sale 2355 / Lot 23], christies.com, retrieved 21 November 2011.</ref>
===Primary and secondary markets=== The art market as a whole is affected by its two main parts: the primary art market, where new art comes to the market for the first time, and the secondary market, for existing art that has been sold at least once before. Once a work is sold on the primary market it enters the secondary market, and the prices for which it sold in the primary market have a direct bearing on the work's value in the secondary market. Supply and demand affect the secondary market more than the primary market because works new to the market, mainly contemporary art, have no market history for predictive analysis and thus valuation of such work is more difficult, and more speculative.<ref name="gerald">Gerard and Louis, [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/B6V64-3YRSMF4-28/2/44fafa98be1c97504c5a1fdc722b55ba On pricing the priceless: Comments on the economics of the visual art market], ''European Economic Review'', Elsevier, vol. 39(3-4), April 1995, pp. 509-518. (membership required).</ref> Gallery, dealer, consultant, and agent promotion as well as collectors acting as [[alpha consumer]]s (trend-setters) are the forces at work in valuing primary market works.
===Market entry barriers=== As with [[Blue chip (stock market)|blue-chip]] stocks, works by "blue-chip" or well-known artists are generally valued more highly than works by unknown artists since it is hard to predict how an unknown artist's work will sell, or whether it will sell at all. [[barriers to entry|High barriers to market entry]] for artists<ref name="jeffri">Jeffri, Joan, Philanthropy and the American artist: A historical overview, ''[[International Journal of Cultural Policy|The European Journal of Cultural Policy]]'', 3(2), 2009, pp. 207-233.</ref><ref name="barriers">Jackson, M.R., et al, [http://www.urban.org/UploadedPDF/411311_investing_in_creativity.pdf Investing in Creativity: A study of the support structure for US artists], ''The Journal of Arts Management, Law, and Society'', 2004. PDF from Urban Institute, urban.org.</ref> create scarcity in the supply and demand portion of the market, in turn driving up prices and raising questions of [[Financial market efficiency|efficiency]].<ref name="bonus">Bonus, H., Ronte, D., Credibility and economic value in the visual arts, ''Journal of Cultural Economics'' 21, 1997 103–118.</ref><ref name="adler">Adler, M., [http://www.columbia.edu/~ma820/Stardom%20and%20Talent.pdf ''Stardom and Talent''], in Handbook of the Economics of Art and Culture, Vol. 1, Chap. 25, 2006, pp. 895-906.</ref> While a high market entry barrier may result in having a smaller pool of artwork producers in the auction-level portion of the market, and in greater market predictability by virtue of that smaller pool and thus more reliable valuation measures, its axiomatic effect is of lesser artistic diversity negatively impacting the size of the buyer pool.<ref name="schonfeld">Schönfeld and Reinstaller, [http://www.wu-wien.ac.at/inst/vw1/papers/wu-wp90.pdf ''The effects of gallery and artist reputation on prices in the primary market for art'']{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Working Paper, Department of Economics, Vienna University of Economics & B.A., May 2005.</ref> For this reason, gallerists and art dealers consider what types of works are currently in vogue before deciding to represent a new artist and are highly selective in those choices in order to maintain a level of quality that is saleable. All these concerns are in play when gallerists set prices for emerging artists at a much lower level than for established artists.
===Market transparency=== With the [[2007–2012 global financial crisis]], the art market faced criticism for its lack of transparency, its [[Byzantinism|Byzantine]] valuation methods, and a perceived lack of ethical behavior enabled by structural inadequacies in the market itself. In response, a 2009 debate occurred between valuation-setting members of the art market on the proposition that "the art market is less ethical than the stock market". At the end of the debate the audience determined that those debating in agreement with the proposition won the debate.<ref name="morality">Saltz, Jerry, [http://www.artnet.com/magazineus/features/saltz/saltz3-6-09.asp Morality Play], artnet.com, 2009-03-06, discussing the debate and its outcome. Participants included art dealers Richard Feigen and Michael Hue-Williams, collector Adam Lindemann on the "pro" side, and artist [[Chuck Close]], critic Jerry Saltz, and auctioneer Amy Cappellazzo opposing. The [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xpsTNdYeG6U debate video] is available on [[YouTube]].</ref> Of particular note in the debate was the identification of "chandelier bidding" as a practice perceived as ethically questionable. The debaters described "chandelier bidding" as bids from the chandelier, or bids from an unknown source, meaning both the bidding by the auction houses on behalf of the sellers whose items the houses are auctioning (a [[conflict of interest]]), and bidding by unidentified bidders having no intention of buying but bidding in order to drive prices up, all practiced because the auction houses keep secret from bidders a seller's [[Reservation price|reserve price]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/28/arts/design/as-art-market-rise-so-do-questions-of-oversight.html|title=As Art Market Soars, So Do Questions of Oversight|last=Pogrebin|first=Robin|date=27 January 2013|work=The New York Times|access-date=9 June 2017|last2=Flynn|first2=Kevin|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
In 2011, also in response to criticism on the lack of market transparency and counterarguments that more transparency would ruin the market,<ref name="adaa">Art Dealers Association of America (ADAA), [http://www.artdealers.org/events.forum30.html Art Industry Summit] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111216122400/http://www.artdealers.org/events.forum30.html |date=16 December 2011 }}, Transparency in the market: can we have more of it?, 3 March 2011.</ref> ''[[The Art Newspaper]]'' in association with the Art Dealers Association of America convened an Art Industry Summit panel discussion between major art market decision makers, where panelists discussed whether there was a need for more transparency.<ref name="transpADAA">ADAA and The Art Newspaper, Transparency in the market...can we have more of it?, videos [http://www.theartnewspaper.tv/content.php?vid=1662 Part 1] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304193922/http://www.theartnewspaper.tv/content.php?vid=1662# |date=2016-03-04 }}, [http://www.theartnewspaper.tv/content.php?vid=1661 Part 2] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305172450/http://theartnewspaper.tv/content.php?vid=1661# |date=2016-03-05 }}, and [http://www.theartnewspaper.tv/content.php?vid=1660 Part 3] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304110955/http://www.theartnewspaper.tv/content.php?vid=1660# |date=2016-03-04 }}, Host Anna Somers Cocks, ''The Art Newpapaper'', 11 March 2011.</ref> The panelists argued over whether auction houses have built-in conflicts of interest by representing sellers with secret reserves, while at the same time representing to buyers initial valuations on those works at auction time. The debate also included the issue of first and third-party guaranteed bids, and whether sellers' reserve prices should be disclosed so that participants no longer bid on an object they have no chance of buying. In response to criticisms regarding chandelier bidding and unidentified third-party guaranteed bids, Christie's International chairman Edward Dolman countered that, without a secret reserve, illegal cartels of bidders would know in advance information that could facilitate their manipulation of the market and corruption of final valuation by selling price at auction.<ref name="transpADAA2">ADAA, video 3 at 22:05 min, et seq..</ref>
With the art market's weaknesses (especially lack of transparency and conflicts of interests) becoming better known, serious external conversations about market regulation have begun among major market players; for example, the ''[[Financial Times]]'' noted that in early 2015, participants at the January [[World Economic Forum]] meeting attended a lunch seminar where the speaker warned that the global art market needs to be regulated because of systemic weaknesses which enable inside information trading, tax evasion, and money laundering.<ref name="gapper">Gapper, John, [https://web.archive.org/web/20150125081849/http://blogs.ft.com/the-world/2015/01/art-worlds-shady-dealings-under-scrutiny-at-davos Art world’s shady dealings under scrutiny at Davos], ''[[Financial Times]]'', 22 January 2015. Accessed 17 November 2015.</ref>
In terms of academic research, there is work on the opacity of price formation in finance and economics.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=David|first=Géraldine|last2=Oosterlinck|first2=Kim|last3=Szafarz|first3=Ariane|title=Art market inefficiency|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.econlet.2013.06.033|journal=Economics Letters|volume=121|issue=1|pages=23–25|doi=10.1016/j.econlet.2013.06.033}}</ref><ref name=":0" />
== Auction house market structure == The late 1980s were a boom period for art auction houses. However, in early 1990, the market collapsed. The US overtook the EU as the world's largest art market<ref>{{Citation | last1 = Knelman | first1 = Josh | title = Art Theft: Not Such a Pretty Picture | newspaper = [[Toronto Standard]] | date = 5 December 2011 | url = http://www.torontostandard.com/culture-design/art-theft-not-such-a-pretty-picture | accessdate = 28 April 2012 }}</ref> with a global share of 47 per cent by 2001.<ref>{{Citation | last = Bennett | first = Will | title = Red tape and taxes cost Europe lead in art market | newspaper = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | location = London | date = 8 March 2002 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/1387151/Red-tape-and-taxes-cost-Europe-lead-in-art-market.html | accessdate = October 1, 2012 }}</ref> Ranking second, the UK's world market share hovers around 25 per cent. In continental Europe, France was the market leader while in Asia, Hong Kong continues its dominance. France’s share of the art market has been progressively eroded since the 1950s, when it was the dominant location and sales at Drouot surpassed those of Sotheby’s and Christie’s combined.<ref>{{cite news|last=Adam |first=Georgina |title=Opinion: One-offs, but reassuring signs to the market—especially to Paris? |newspaper=[[The Art Newspaper]] |date=April 1, 2009 |url=http://www.theartnewspaper.com/article.asp?id=17186 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090409071446/http://www.theartnewspaper.com/article.asp?id=17186 |archivedate=April 9, 2009 }}</ref> In 2004, the global fine art market turnover was estimated at almost billion.<ref>[http://press.artprice.com/pdf/Trends2004.pdf Art market trends 2004] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101116174818/http://press.artprice.com/pdf/trends2004.pdf# |date=2010-11-16 }}, Artprice, artprice.com, 2005.</ref> Art auction sales reached a record billion in 2007, fueled by speculative bidding for artists such as [[Damien Hirst]], [[Jeff Koons]], and [[Richard Prince]].<ref>{{cite news | last = Reyburn | first = Scott | title = Richter Tops Hot Artists as New Buyers Boost Billion Sales | agency = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | date = December 28, 2011 | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-12-28/richter-tops-hot-artists-as-2011-sales-surge-to-1-7-billion-on-new-buyers.html}}</ref> The recent rise of the Chinese art market, both in terms of the size of its domestic sales and the international significance of its buyers, has, combined with a rich cultural heritage of art and antiques, produced a huge domestic market and ended the duopoly held by London and New York for over 50 years.<ref>Clare McAndrew (March 14, 2013), [http://theartnewspaper.com/articles/US-retakes-top-spot-in-art-sales-from-China-/29104 US retakes top spot in art sales from China] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130318200710/http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/US-retakes-top-spot-in-art-sales-from-China-/29104 |date=2013-03-18 }} ''[[The Art Newspaper]]''.</ref>
=== Competitors === Christie's and Sotheby's are the leading auction venues. In 2002, [[LVMH]] acquired Swiss art advisory firm de Pury & Luxembourg and merged it with Phillips to form [[Phillips de Pury & Company]], with the aim of breaking the duopoly at the top of the market.
=== Segments === Fine art auctions are generally held separately for Impressionist and Modern art as well as for Post-war and Contemporary Art. [[Pablo Picasso]]'s works remain the most coveted lot as of 2004. In 2008 just over million of art by [[Damien Hirst]] was sold at auction, a world record for a living artist; however in 2009, Hirst’s annual auction sales had shrunk by 93%.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Hands up for Hirst - How the bad boy of Brit-Art grew rich at the expense of his investors | magazine = [[The Economist]] | date = September 9, 2010 | url = http://www.economist.com/node/16990811}}</ref>
=== Estimates === "Estimates" often reflect the [[consignor]]'s ambitions as much as the auction specialist's considered opinion. They do not reflect commissions. To secure consignments, auction houses concede high estimates to suit the requirements of art owners.<ref>Souren Melikian, [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/08/arts/08iht-melikian08.html When Auction Estimates Go Haywire], ''[[The New York Times]]'', nytimes.com, October 7, 2011.</ref> Before an auction, interested buyers typically turn for advice to the auction house specialist who quotes the estimate and often recommends going beyond in order to secure the item.<ref>Souren Melikian, [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/18/arts/18iht-melik19.1.9319140.html Behind stellar sales of art market, a dangerous game], ''The New York Times'', nytimes.com, January 18, 2008.</ref>
=== Commissions and Buyer's Premium === Auction houses operate contractually on behalf of sellers of goods, charging sellers a fixed [[commission (remuneration)|commission]] (fee) amounting to a percentage of the “hammer price” for which a lot is sold.<ref name="horror">{{cite journal | title = Hammer houses of horror | magazine = [[The Economist]] | date = July 24, 1997 | url = http://www.economist.com/node/152446 | accessdate = 2012-11-20}}</ref> Christie's published its commissions in September 1995, with its fees ranging from 20% on the least expensive lots to 2% on lots sold for over m; Sotheby's followed suit.<ref name="horror" /> For Phillips de Pury & Company, final prices include commission of 25% of the first 20% of the next to million, and 12% of the rest, with estimates not reflecting commissions.<ref>Carol Vogel, [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/14/arts/design/14auction.html Phillips Sale Totals Less Than Half the Low Estimate] ''The New York Times'', nytimes.com, November 13, 2008.</ref> Objects sold are also subject to a further fee called the "[[buyer's premium]]", 15% being typical, with the term implying that by virtue of selling an object, the auction house performs a service for the buyer subject to remuneration. Thus, both the seller and the buyer of an object or lot sold by the major auction houses pay a fee. First implemented in 1975 by Christie's, the assessment of a buyer's premium is one of several auction-house practices to which art dealers object.<ref>Orley Ashenfelter & Kathryn Graddy, Anatomy of the Rise and Fall of a Pricefixing Conspiracy: Auctions At Sotheby’s And Christie’s, ''Journal of Competition Law and Economics'', 1(1), 3–20, March 2005, {{doi|10.1093/joclec/nhi003}}.</ref>
=== Performance-based fees === Beginning in 2014, Christie's charged 2 percent of the hammer price of a work that meets or exceeds its high estimate. The fee does not apply to online only sales.<ref>Melanie Gerlis (September 26, 2014), [http://theartnewspaper.com/articles/Christies-takes-another-/35708 Christie's takes another 2%] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140928075542/http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Christies-takes-another-/35708 |date=2014-09-28 }} ''[[The Art Newspaper]]''.</ref>
=== Guarantees === An auction house may offer a guaranteed selling price, or "guaranteed minimum", a practice designed to give sellers confidence to consign works and to give potential bidders reassurance that there are others willing to buy an item.<ref>[[Sarah Thornton]], [https://www.economist.com/blogs/prospero/2011/11/art-market Financial machinations at auctions], ''The Economist'', economist.com, November 18, 2011.</ref> Auction houses have offered guarantees since the early 1970s to encourage collectors to sell their artworks: ''The Art Newspaper'' reported that guarantees were first introduced in 1971 at Sotheby’s, when 47 [[Wassily Kandinsky|Kandinsky]]s and other works from the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum|Guggenheim Museum]] were offered with a guaranteed minimum; similar arrangements followed in 1972 and 1973 for the Ritter and Scull collections.<ref>{{Citation | last1 = Adam | first1 = Georgina | last2 = Burns | first2 = Charlotte | title = Guaranteed outcome | newspaper = [[The Art Newspaper]] | date = 2 March 2011 | url = http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Guaranteed+outcome/23341 | accessdate = 12 November 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | last1 = Feinstein | first1 = Roni | title = The Scull Collection | magazine = [[Art in America]] | date = 4 June 2010 | url = http://www.artinamericamagazine.com/reviews/the-scull-collection/ | accessdate = 12 November 2012 }}</ref> A guaranteed amount is generally close to the lower estimate, with the seller and the auction house sharing any amount exceeding the guaranteed minimum.<ref>{{Citation | last1 = Melikian | first1 = Souren | title = Behind stellar sales of art market, a dangerous game | magazine = [[The New York Times]] | date = 18 January 2008 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/18/arts/18iht-melik19.1.9319140.html | accessdate = 12 November 2012 }}</ref> In autumn 2008 when the market turned sour, Christie's and Sotheby's had to pay out at least million on works for which they guaranteed a minimum price but which failed to sell. In order to reduce their exposure to such losses, boost the market, and reduce volatility, the main auction houses now prefer that third parties take on this financial risk via "third-party guarantees" or "irrevocable bids": using this practice the auction houses sell a work to a third party for a minimum price prior to the auction and this selling price then becomes the “reserve” below which the artwork will not be sold. If bidding for specified works stops at the minimum price, which remains undisclosed, the "third party" acquires the lot; if bidding exceeds the reserve, the third party splits any profit from its sale with the consignor and with the auction house, the percentage going to each party varying with the deal.<ref>{{Citation | last1 = Tully | first1 = Judd | title = Assurance Policies: Third-Party Guarantees May Reduce Risk and Yield Rewards | date = 22 September 2011 | publisher = [[Louise Blouin Media|Artinfo]] | year = | url = http://www.artinfo.com/news/story/38646/assurance-policies-third-party-guarantees-may-reduce-risk-and-yield-rewards/ | accessdate = 12 November 2012 }}</ref> These proportions, never disclosed to the public, are negotiated before an auction and specified in the contract signed by the auction house and the third party.<ref>Souren Melikian, [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/06/arts/06iht-melik6.html Picasso Sells at Record Auction Price], ''The New York Times'', nytimes.com, May 5, 2010.</ref>
=== Online sales === [[File:Teo Spiller net.art.trade (net.art).jpg|thumb|A Screenshot of Teo Spiller's net.art net.art.trade]] In May 1999, [[Teo Spiller]] sold a web art project Megatronix to Ljubljana Municipal Museum, which was by the New York Times announced as the first sell of an [[Internet art]] [[net.art]].<ref>Mirapaul, M [http://partners.nytimes.com/library/tech/99/05/cyber/artsatlarge/13artsatlarge.html "There May Be Money in Internet Art After All"], ''The New York Times, 1999-05-13''</ref>
In 2003, Sotheby's abandoned its partnership with [[eBay]] after it lost millions through its various attempts to sell fine art over the internet.<ref name="duopoly">[http://www.economist.com/node/1612774 Just the two of us - The duopoly in fine-art auctions is weakened but very much alive] ''The Economist'', economist.com, February 27, 2003.</ref>
==What Counts== The [[art sale|art market]] can also be used to understand what “counts” as part of art history. [[Art dealers]] and auctioneers organize material for distribution to collectors. Two of the largest, and oldest, art auction houses are [[Sotheby's]] and [[Christie's]], and each hold frequent sales of great [[antiquities]] and [[Art Object|art objects]].
==Black Market== In addition to upstanding practices, a [[black market]] exists for great art, which is closely tied to [[art theft]] and [[art forgery]]. No auction houses or dealers admit openly to participating in the black market because of its illegality, but exposés suggest widespread problems in the field. Because demand for art objects is high, and security in many parts of the world is low, a thriving trade in [[illicit antiquities]] acquired through [[looting]] also exists. Although the art community nearly universally condemns looting because it results in destruction of [[Archaeological site|archeological sites]], [[looted art]] paradoxically remains omnipresent. Warfare is correlated with such looting, as is demonstrated by the recent [[archaeological looting in Iraq]].

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Use British English|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Carey Mulligan | image = Carey Mulligan in 2016.jpg | caption = Mulligan in 2016 | birth_name = Carey Hannah Mulligan | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1985|5|28}} | birth_place = [[City of Westminster|Westminster]], [[London]], England | education = [[International School of Düsseldorf]]
[[Woldingham School]] | occupation = Actress | years_active = 2004–present | spouse = {{marriage|[[Marcus Mumford]]|2012}} | children = 2 }} '''Carey Hannah Mulligan'''''England & Wales, 1984-2004.'' Gives name at birth as "Carey Hannah Mulligan" (born 28 May 1985){{cite web|url=http://www.insidebayarea.com/ci_15177132?|first=Randy|last=McMullen|title=People: Crystal Bowersox split with boyfriend day before 'Idol' finale|work=The Oakland Tribune|publisher=Bay Area News Group |date=27 May 2010|accessdate=29 May 2010}} is an English actress. Born in [[London]] and brought up in [[Düsseldorf|Düsseldorf, Germany]] and [[Surrey]], Mulligan developed an interest in acting as a child and was the student head of the drama department at [[Woldingham School]]. She made her professional acting debut on stage in the [[Kevin Elyot]] play ''Forty Winks'' at the [[Royal Court Theatre]] in 2004. Her film debut was in the role of Kitty Bennet in ''[[Pride & Prejudice (2005 film)|Pride & Prejudice]]'' (2005), followed by supporting roles in numerous television series, including ''[[Bleak House (2005 TV serial)|Bleak House]]'' (2005), ''[[The Amazing Mrs Pritchard]]'' (2006), and ''[[Doctor Who]]'' (2007). She made her [[Broadway (theatre)|Broadway]] debut in ''[[The Seagull]]'' in 2008 to critical acclaim, and her [[West End theatre|West End]] performance garnered her an [[Ian Charleson Awards|Ian Charleson Commendation Award]]. Mulligan's breakthrough performance was as Jenny Mellor in the coming-of-age drama ''[[An Education]]'' (2009), for which she won the [[BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Leading Role]], and was nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Actress]]. Her leading role in the dystopian romantic-drama [[Never Let Me Go (2010 film)|''Never Let Me Go'']] (2010) earned her a [[BIFA Award for Best Performance by an Actress in a British Independent Film]], and she garnered further acclaim for her supporting performances in the action film [[Drive (2011 film)|''Drive'']] (2011), for which she was nominated for the [[BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Supporting Role]], and the drama ''[[Shame (2011 film)|Shame]]'' (2011). Her appearances in [[The Great Gatsby (2013 film)|''The Great Gatsby'']] (2013), ''[[Inside Llewyn Davis]]'' (2013), ''[[Far from the Madding Crowd (2015 film)|Far from the Madding Crowd]]'' (2015), and ''[[Suffragette (film)|Suffragette]]'' (2015) earned her further praise and recognition. In 2015, she was nominated for a [[Tony Award for Best Performance by a Leading Actress in a Play|Tony Award for Best Lead Actress in a Play]] for her performance in the Broadway revival of [[David Hare (playwright)|David Hare]]'s ''[[Skylight (play)|Skylight]]''. In 2017, she starred in the critically acclaimed period drama film ''[[Mudbound (film)|Mudbound]]'', and the following year starred in the thriller series [[Collateral (TV series)|''Collateral'']]. Apart from her acting career, Mulligan is noted for her philanthropic efforts, and has been an ambassador for [[Alzheimer's Society]] since 2012, and an ambassador for [[War Child (charity)|War Child]] since 2014. She has been married to English singer-songwriter [[Marcus Mumford]] since 2012, with whom she has two children. ==Early life== Mulligan was born in [[Westminster]], [[London]],Hornby, Nick [https://web.archive.org/web/20131117051213/http://www.elle.com/pop-culture/reviews/shes-the-one-3/ "She's the One"] ''Archived from Elle''Muller, Matt [http://www.mattmueller.co.uk/index.php?page_id=Interviews%20/%20Features&category_id=Interviews&article_id=402 "There's Something About Carey"] ''Total Film'' the daughter of Nano ([[married and maiden names|née]] Booth) and Stephen Mulligan. Her father is of Irish descent and was originally from [[Liverpool]]. Her mother is from [[Llandeilo]], Wales.{{cite news|last=Rees|first=Claire |title=Mum keeps my feet on ground, says Oscar hopeful Carey Mulligan|publisher=Wales Online|date=7 February 2010|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/showbiz-and-lifestyle/showbiz/2010/02/07/mum-keeps-my-feet-on-ground-says-oscar-hopeful-carey-mulligan-91466-25778500/|accessdate=18 February 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/features/2009/1028/1224257549716.html|author=Anna Carey|title=Life lessons captured on film |work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|date=28 October 2009|accessdate=21 December 2009}}{{subscription}} Her mother is a university lecturer and her father is a hotel manager. Her parents met while they were both working in a hotel in their twenties. When she was three years old, her family moved to Germany when her father was hired to manage a hotel there. While living in Germany, Mulligan and her brother attended the [[International School of Düsseldorf]].Abramowitz, Rachel [http://articles.latimes.com/2009/oct/08/entertainment/et-mulligan8 "Carey Mulligan Gets An Education"] ''Los Angeles Times'' When she was eight, she and her family moved back to England. As a teenager, she was educated at [[Woldingham School]] in [[Surrey]].{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/baftas/7271959/Carey-Mulligan-her-journey-from-school-stage-to-Baftas-red-carpet.html|title=Carey Mulligan: her journey from school stage to Bafta's red carpet|date=20 February 2010|publisher=Telegraph.co.uk|author=Anita Singh|accessdate=10 April 2012}} ==Interest in acting== Her interest in acting sparked from watching her brother perform in a school production of ''[[The King and I]]'' when she was six. During rehearsals, she pleaded with his teachers to let her be in the play. They let her join the chorus. While enrolled in Woldingham School as a teen, she was heavily involved in theatre. She was the student head of the drama department there, performing in plays and musicals, conducting workshops with younger students, and helping put on productions.{{cite web |title=Actress Carey's Pride and Joy(archived) |url=http://icsouthlondon.icnetwork.co.uk/0100news/0225croydon/tm_objectid=16165216&method=full&siteid=53340&headline=actress-carey-s-pride-and-joy-name_page.html |work=ICSouthLondon.co.uk |author=Emily Attwood |author2=Brian Haran |last-author-amp=yes |date=23 September 2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060220105613/http://icsouthlondon.icnetwork.co.uk/0100news/0225croydon/tm_objectid%3D16165216%26method%3Dfull%26siteid%3D53340%26headline%3Dactress-carey-s-pride-and-joy-name_page.html |archivedate=20 February 2006 |df=dmy-all }}staff [http://abcnews.go.com/widgets/mediaViewer/image?id=9931402 "ABC News Mulligan"]. ''AbcNews'' When she was 16, she attended a production of ''[[Henry V (play)|Henry V]]'' starring [[Kenneth Branagh]]. His performance emboldened her and reinforced her belief that she wanted to pursue a career in acting. She wrote a letter to Branagh asking him for advice. "I explained that my parents didn't want me to act, but that I felt it was my vocation in life," she said. Branagh's sister replied: "Kenneth says that if you feel such a strong need to be an actress, you must be an actress."Fox, Chloe [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/3669189/Carey-Mulligan-All-or-nothing.html "Carey Mulligan All or Nothing"]. ''The Telegraph''. Mulligan's parents disapproved of her acting ambitions and wished for her to attend a university like her brother. At age 17, she applied to three London drama schools, instead of the universities that she was expected to submit an application to, but did not receive a subsequent offer. During her final year at Woldingham School, actor/screenwriter [[Julian Fellowes]] delivered a lecture at the school on the production of the film ''[[Gosford Park]]''. Mulligan briefly talked to him after the lecture and asked him for advice on an acting career. However, Fellowes dissuaded her from the profession and suggested that she "marry a lawyer" instead. Undeterred, she later sent Fellowes a letter in which she stated that she was serious about acting and that the vocation was her purpose in life. Several weeks later, Fellowes's wife Emma invited her to a dinner for young, aspiring actors that she and her husband were hosting to offer advice. The event facilitated an introduction between Mulligan and a casting assistant that led to an audition for a role in ''Pride and Prejudice''. She auditioned on three occasions and was eventually given the role of Kitty Bennet.Fuller, Graham [http://www.theartsdesk.com/features/actress-carey-mulligan-emotionally-speaking "Actress Carey Mulligan, Emotionally Speaking"] "The Arts Desk"Buck, Joan [http://www.vogue.com/magazine/article/the-talented-miss-mulligan "The Talented Miss Mulligan"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115020514/http://www.vogue.com/magazine/article/the-talented-miss-mulligan/ |date=15 January 2013 }} ''Vogue''Clements, Erin [http://www.elle.com/_mobile/news/culture/three-things-to-know-about-an-education-star-carey-mulligan-1755 "Three Things to Know About An Education Star Carey Mulligan"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222190852/http://www.elle.com/_mobile/news/culture/three-things-to-know-about-an-education-star-carey-mulligan-1755# |date=22 February 2014 }} "Elle.com" During her late teens and early twenties, she worked as a [[pub]] barmaid and an errand-runner for Ealing Studios in between acting jobs.Staff [http://www.hamhigh.co.uk/news/carey_mulligan_returns_home_empty_handed_from_oscars_1_632715 "Carey Mulligan Returns Home"] Hamhigh.co.uk, ==Career== [[File:CareyMulliganPeterSarsgaardOct2009.jpg|thumb|Mulligan with [[Peter Sarsgaard]]]] In 2004, at the age of 19, Mulligan began her acting on stage in the play ''Forty Winks'' at the [[Royal Court Theatre]] in London.Billington, Michael [http://www.guardiannews.com/stage/2004/nov/04/theatre "Forty Winks Guardian Review"] "The Guardian"Spencer, Charles [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/drama/3626618/A-dramatist-recycling-himself.html "Forty Winks Telegraph Review"] "The Telegraph" She made her film debut the following year in ''[[Pride & Prejudice (2005 film)|Pride & Prejudice]]'', the 2005 film adaptation of [[Pride & Prejudice|the Jane Austen novel]], portraying Kitty Bennet. Later that year, she auditioned for and won the role of orphan Ada Clare in the [[British Academy Television Awards|BAFTA award]]-winning BBC adaption of [[Charles Dickens]]' ''[[Bleak House (2005 TV serial)|Bleak House]]'', her television debut.staff [http://www.scotsman.com/news/why-carey-s-delighted-to-be-an-orphan-1-967676 "Why Carey's Delighted to be an Orphan"]''The Scotsman'' Among her 2007 projects were ''[[My Boy Jack (film)|My Boy Jack]]'', starring [[Daniel Radcliffe]], that features her in a supporting role, and ''[[Northanger Abbey (2007 film)|Northanger Abbey]]''. She identified with her role [[Elsie Kipling|Elsie]], the daughter of writer [[Rudyard Kipling]], who vociferously opposes her brother going to war. She earned a [[Constellation Award]] for playing the main character Sally Sparrow in the ''[[Doctor Who]]'' episode "[[Blink (Doctor Who)|Blink]]".{{cite web |url=http://constellations.tcon.ca/2008.shtml |title=2008 Constellation Awards |publisher=Constellation Awards |accessdate=20 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rZ6XiZty?url=http://constellations.tcon.ca/2008.shtml |archivedate=28 July 2010 |df=dmy-all }} She rounded out 2007 by appearing in an acclaimed revival of ''[[The Seagull#Translating The Seagull|The Seagull]]'', in which she played Nina to [[Kristin Scott Thomas]]'s Arkadina and [[Chiwetel Ejiofor]]'s Trigorin. ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' said her performance was "quite extraordinarily radiating'" and ''[[The Observer]]'' called her "almost unbearably affecting." While in the middle of the production, she had to have an [[appendectomy]], preventing her from being able to perform for a week.{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/3669189/Carey-Mulligan-All-or-nothing.html |date=10 October 2007 |title=Carey Mulligan: All or nothing |author=Chloe Fox |work=The Daily Telegraph |publisher=Telegraph Media Group |accessdate=20 December 2009}} For her debut Broadway performance in the 2008 American transfer of ''The Seagull'', she was nominated for a [[Drama Desk Award]], but lost to [[Angela Lansbury]].{{cite web |url=http://theater.about.com/od/behindthescenes/a/dramadesknoms09.htm |year=2009 |author=Paul Cozby |title='Billy Elliot' Nabs Drama Desk Best Musical |publisher=[[About.com]] |accessdate=18 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707075145/http://theater.about.com/od/behindthescenes/a/dramadesknoms09.htm |archivedate=7 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Her big breakthrough came when, at 22, she was cast in her first leading role as Jenny in the 2009 independent film ''An Education'', directed by Danish filmmaker [[Lone Scherfig]] and written by [[Nick Hornby]]. Over a hundred actresses auditioned for the part, but Mulligan's audition impressed Scherfig the most.{{cite web |url=http://www.filmjournal.com/filmjournal/content_display/esearch/e3i7c69fb437bbee15e8a99ffeaed76a9af|date=22 September 2009 |work=FilmJournal |publisher=FilmJournal|title=Educating Carey: Lone Scherfig's '60s Tale Grooms a New Movie Star |author=Harry Haun |accessdate=18 December 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.wmagazine.com/celebrities/2010/02/lone_scherfig?currentPage=1 |date=10 February 2010 |work=WMagazine |publisher=WMagazine |title=Lone Scherfig |author=Diane Solway |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130606074611/http://www.wmagazine.com/celebrities/2010/02/lone_scherfig?currentPage=1 |archivedate=6 June 2013 |df=dmy-all }} The film and her performance received rave reviews, and she was nominated for an [[Academy Award]], [[Screen Actors Guild]], [[Golden Globe]], and won a [[British Academy Film Award|BAFTA Award]]. Lisa Schwarzbaum of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' and Todd McCarthy of ''Variety'' both compared her performance to that of [[Audrey Hepburn]].{{cite web |url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117939422.html?u=IMDB&p=H2BE&cs=1 |date=21 January 2009 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |publisher=Reed Business Information|title=An Education |author=Todd McCarthy |accessdate=18 December 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20310598,00.html |date=7 October 2009 |author=Lisa Schwarzbaum |title=An Education (2009) |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |publisher=Time Warner Inc. |accessdate=18 December 2009}} [[Rolling Stone (magazine)|''Rolling Stone'']]'s [[Peter Travers]] described her as having given a "sensational, starmaking performance,"{{cite news |title=Education |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/reviews/an-education-20091009 |work=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]] |publisher=Wenner Media LLC |first=Peter |last=Travers |date=8 October 2009 |accessdate=10 March 2011}} while Claudia Puig of ''[[USA Today]]'' felt that Mulligan had one of the year's best performances,{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/reviews/2009-10-08-an-education_N.htm |title='An Education' teaches a vivid lesson in life, love |work=[[USA Today]] |date=9 October 2009 |author=Claudia Puig |accessdate=18 December 2009}} and [[Toby Young]] of ''[[The Times]]'' felt she anchored the film.{{cite web |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/film/film_reviews/article6895553.ece |title=An Education |publisher=The Times UK |date=30 October 2009 |author=Toby Young |accessdate=3 January 2010}} Writing in ''[[The Guardian]]'', [[Peter Bradshaw]] concluded that she gave a "wonderful performance."{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2009/oct/29/an-education-review |title=An Education |date=29 October 2009 |author=Peter Bradshaw |work=[[The Guardian]] |publisher=Guardian News and Media |accessdate=3 January 2010}} Mulligan was a recipient of the [[Shooting Stars Award]] from the 2009 [[Berlin International Film Festival]]{{cite news |title=EFP jury chooses 2009 Shooting Stars |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=9 December 2008}}{{Registration required}} and received a BAFTA Rising Star Award nomination, which is voted on by the British public. Mulligan next starred in independent film ''[[The Greatest (2009 film)|The Greatest]]'' (2009) as the pregnant girlfriend of a boy who dies. Her involvement with the project helped it "tremendously", according to the director.{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/melissa-silverstein/interview-with-shana-fest_b_523165.html |title=Interview with Shana Feste -- Writer and Director of The Greatest |first=Melissa |last=Silverstein |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |publisher=HuffingtonPost.com, Inc. |date=2 April 2010 |accessdate=21 May 2010}} After being selected to join [[The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]],{{cite web |url=http://oscar-watch.ew.com/2010/06/25/academy-new-members-bono-gabourey-sidibe/ |title=Academy Invites 135 New Members |work=Entertainment Weekly |publisher=Time Warner Inc. |first=Dave |last=Karger |date=25 June 2010 |accessdate=27 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100627125218/http://oscar-watch.ew.com/2010/06/25/academy-new-members-bono-gabourey-sidibe/ |archivedate=27 June 2010 |df=dmy }} she won a British Independent Award for ''[[Never Let Me Go (2010 film)|Never Let Me Go]]'', an adaption of the 2005 [[Kazuo Ishiguro]]'s novel, in which she starred and narrated. It was released in September 2010, competing against her other project, the [[Oliver Stone]]-directed film ''[[Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps]]''.{{cite news |title=After her breakout year, Carey Mulligan still garnering praise for acting |author=Homaday, Ann |work=Washington Post |publisher=The Washington Post Company |date=24 September 2010}} Screened out of competition at the [[2010 Cannes Film Festival]],{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/news/mike-leigh-%20%20%20%20film-in-running-for-palme-dor-1945887.html |title=Mike Leigh film in running for Palme D'Or |first=Sherna |last=Noah |publisher=Independent Print Limited |work=[[The Independent]] |date=15 April 2010|accessdate=15 April 2010}} it was her first major studio project.{{cite news |title=Carey Mulligan joins 'Wall Street 2' |author=Boyrs Kit |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=13 August 2009}}{{Registration required}} Later that year she also provided vocals for the song "[[Write About Love (song)|Write About Love]]" by [[Belle & Sebastian]].[http://pitchfork.com/news/39957-new-belle-and-sebastian-write-about-love/ "New Belle and Sebastian: "Write About Love" "] 7 September 2010, Pitchfork She returned to the stage in the [[Atlantic Theater Company]]'s off-Broadway play adaptation of [[Ingmar Bergman]]'s ''[[Through a Glass Darkly (film)|Through a Glass, Darkly]]'', from 13 May – 3 July 2011.{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/carey-mulligan-play-woman-battling-71552 |title=Carey Mulligan to Play Woman Battling Psychiatric Illness on New York Stage |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=13 January 2011 |accessdate=13 January 2011}} Mulligan played the central character, a mentally unstable woman, and received glowing praise from reviewers.{{cite web |url=http://www.instyle.co.uk/news/carey-mulligan-gets-rave-reviews-for-new-play-07-06-11 |title=Carey Mulligan gets rave reviews for new play |work=[[InStyle]] |first=Maria |last=Milano |publisher=Time Warner Inc. |date=7 June 2011 |accessdate=8 June 2011}} [[Ben Brantley]], theater critic for ''[[The New York Times]]'', wrote that Mulligan's performance was "acting of the highest order"; he also described her as "extraordinary" and "one of the finest actresses of her generation.",{{cite web|last=Brantley|first=Ben|title=Under Pretty Skin, Madness Lurks|url=http://theater.nytimes.com/2011/06/07/theater/reviews/carey-mulligan-in-through-a-glass-darkly-review.html|publisher=The New York Times}} [[File:Joel Edgerton, Baz Luhrmann, Elizabeth Debicki, Carey Mulligan, Tobey Maguire and Catherine Martin.jpg|thumb|Mulligan with the cast of ''[[The Great Gatsby (2013 film)|The Great Gatsby]]'' (2013)]] Mulligan co-starred in the critically acclaimed 2011 [[neo-noir]] thriller ''[[Drive (2011 film)|Drive]]'', directed by Danish filmmaker [[Nicolas Winding Refn]]. She was nominated for her second [[BAFTA]] award—Best Supporting Actress—for the film. ''Drive'' garnered a total of 4 [[BAFTA]] award nominations, including Best Picture and Best Director.Staff [https://www.theguardian.com/film/2012/jan/17/baftas-2012-shortlist "2012 BAFTA Nominations"]''The Guardian'' She began filming [[Steve McQueen (director)|Steve McQueen]]'s sex-addiction drama ''[[Shame (2011 film)|Shame]]'' alongside [[Michael Fassbender]] in New York in January 2011.{{cite web|title=Michael Fassbender to star with Carey Mulligan in New York movie about sex|url=http://www.irishcentral.com/ent/Michael-Fassbender-to-star-with-Carey-Mulligan-in-New-York-movie-about-sex-110630629.html|work=Irish Central|publisher=Irish Central LLC|author=Hayes, Cathy|accessdate=26 November 2010}} ''Drive'' debuted at 2011 [[Cannes Film Festival]] and ''Shame'' debuted at 2011 [[Venice Film Festival]], both to good reviews. Of her performance in ''Shame'', ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' film critic [[Peter Travers]] wrote, "Mulligan is in every way sensational."{{cite web|last=Travers|first=Peter|title=Shame movie review|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/reviews/shame-20111201|publisher=Rolling Stone}} She starred as [[Daisy Buchanan]], opposite [[Leonardo DiCaprio]], in ''[[The Great Gatsby (2013 film)|The Great Gatsby]]'', which was released in May 2013.{{cite web |url=http://news-briefs.ew.com/2010/11/15/carey-mulligan-the-great-gatsby |title=Carey Mulligan lands lead role in Baz Luhrmann's film of 'The Great Gatsby' |first=Adam |last=B. Vary |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |publisher=Time Warner Inc. |date=15 November 2010 |accessdate=15 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101120034146/http://news-briefs.ew.com/2010/11/15/carey-mulligan-the-great-gatsby/ |archivedate=20 November 2010 |df=dmy }}{{cite news|title=Divine Daisy! Carey Mulligan gets it right once again at The Great Gatsby premiere in Baz Luhrmann's hometown of Sydney|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/usshowbiz/article-2329055/Carey-Mulligan-gets-right-The-Great-Gatsby-premiere-Baz-Luhrmanns-hometown-Sydney.html|accessdate=28 September 2013|newspaper=Daily Mail|date=22 May 2013|author=George Stark}} Mulligan auditioned for the role of Daisy in late 2010. While attending a ''Vogue'' fashion dinner in New York City in November, [[Baz Luhrmann]]’s wife, Catherine Martin, told her she had the part. In May 2012, she was a co-chair, alongside [[Anna Wintour]], for the Gatsby-themed 2012 [[Met Ball]] Gala.{{cite web |last=Galloway |first=Stephen|title=Baz Luhrmann's Despair, Drive and Gamble Behind 'Great Gatsby'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/great-gatsby-director-baz-luhrmann-444288|work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=24 April 2013}}{{cite web |url= http://runway.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/10/12/prada-and-schiaparelli-at-the-met/ |title=Prada and Schiaparelli at the Met |work=The New York Times |publisher=The New York Times Company |first=Cathy |last=Horyn |date=12 October 2011 |accessdate=30 October 2011}} She starred in the [[Far from the Madding Crowd (2015 film)|film adaptation]] of [[Thomas Hardy]]'s novel ''[[Far from the Madding Crowd]]'' with [[Tom Sturridge]], [[Matthias Schoenaerts]], and [[Michael Sheen]] for director [[Thomas Vinterberg]] and [[Fox Searchlight]].{{cite web|last=McNary|first=David|title=Michael Sheen, Juno Temple Join ‘Far From the Madding Crowd’|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/news/michael-sheen-juno-temple-far-from-the-madding-crowd-1200613350/|work=Variety|publisher=Penske Business Media|accessdate=29 September 2013|date=16 September 2013}}{{cite web|last=White|first=James|title=Carey Mulligan Heads Far From The Madding Crowd|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=108994|work=Empire|publisher=Bauer Consumer Media|accessdate=29 September 2013|date=16 September 2013}} She starred in the June 2014 revival of the play ''[[Skylight (play)|Skylight]]'' with [[Bill Nighy]] and [[Matthew Beard (British actor)|Matthew Beard]], directed by [[Stephen Daldry]], at [[Wyndham's Theatre]] in London's West End.[https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2014/jun/22/skylight-bill-nighy-carey-mulligan-wyndhams-review-hare-revival-thatcherite-play-for-today Skylight review – Hare revival is a Thatcherite play for today] [[The Observer]], 22 June 2014. Retrieved 3 August 2014. It won the [[Evening Standard Award|2014 Evening Standard Theatre Award]] for Revival of the Year and was nominated for the [[Laurence Olivier Award|2014 Olivier Award for Best Revival]].{{cite web|title=Olivier Award Nominations 2015|url=http://www.olivierawards.com/nominations/view/item274537/best-revival/|work=Olivier Awards|date=9 March 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150427184640/http://www.olivierawards.com/nominations/view/item274537/best-revival/|archivedate=27 April 2015|df=dmy-all}} She returned to Broadway when Skylight transferred in April 2015. Her performance as Kyra Hollis was received with critical acclaim and she has received a nomination for the [[Tony Award for Best Performance by a Leading Actress in a Play]].{{cite web|last=Healy Jr.|first=Patrick|title=David Hare’s ‘Skylight’ Coming to Broadway From London|url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/09/03/david-hares-skylight-coming-to-broadway-from-london/|work=New York Times|publisher=The New York Times Company|date=3 September 2014}}{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2015/apr/28/tony-awards-2015-nominations-in-full|title=Tony awards 2015 nominations – in full |work=[[The Guardian]]|date=28 April 2015|accessdate=28 April 2015}} She starred in ''[[Suffragette (film)|Suffragette]]'' for director [[Sarah Gavron]] and screenwriter [[Abi Morgan]], released in October 2015.{{cite web|last=Fleming Jr.|first=Mike|title=Carey Mulligan Eyes Re-Team With ‘Shame’ Scribe In ‘The Fury’|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/07/carey-mulligan-eyes-re-team-with-shame-scribe-in-the-fury/|work=Deadline|publisher=Penske Business Media|date=24 July 2013}} In September 2016, it was announced that she would star opposite [[Jake Gyllenhaal]] in the independent film ''[[Wildlife (film)|Wildlife]]'', the adaptation of a [[Richard Ford]] novel of the same name. The film would be directed by [[Paul Dano]] with a screenplay written by Dano and [[Zoe Kazan]].{{cite web|last=Romano|first=Nick|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/09/23/jake-gyllenhaal-carey-mulligan-paul-dano-wildlife|title=Jake Gyllenhaal and Carey Mulligan join Paul Dano's Wildlife|date=23 September 2016|work=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=1 November 2016}} In November 2017, Mulligan was cast as [[Gloria Steinem]] in ''[[An Uncivil War]]''; the project reunited her with [[Mudbound (film)|Mudbound]] director [[Dee Rees]].{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/carey-mulligan-gloria-steinem-an-uncivil-war-1202606907/|title=Carey Mulligan to Play Gloria Steinem in Dee Rees’ ‘An Uncivil War’ (EXCLUSIVE)|last=Kroll|first=Justin|date=2017-11-04|work=Variety|access-date=2018-11-11|language=en-US}} Mulligan's steely performance as a [[Detective Inspector|detective inspector]] in [[Collateral (TV series)|Collateral]], a [[BBC Two]] limited series, received plaudits from American and British critics, though the series itself garnered mixed reviews.{{Cite news|url=https://www.vulture.com/2018/03/collateral-carey-mulligan-dour-british-detective-show.html|title=If You Like Dour British Detective Shows, Watch Collateral|last=McHenry|first=Jackson|work=Vulture|access-date=2018-11-11|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2018/feb/12/collateral-review-carey-mulligan-shines-in-a-damaging-political-drama|title=Collateral review – Carey Mulligan shines in a damaging political drama|last=Mangan|first=Lucy|date=2018-02-12|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-11-11}} Mulligan praised showrunner [[David Hare (playwright)|Sir David Hare]] for seamlessly accommodating her pregnancy into the script.{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/carey-mulligan-collateral-pregnancy_uk_5a8a92c6e4b00bc49f45eb14|title=Carey Mulligan Praises BBC Writers Who Worked Her Pregnancy Into 'Collateral' Script|date=2018-02-19|work=HuffPost UK|access-date=2018-11-11|language=en-GB}} ==Personal life== [[File:CareyMulligan-Aug-2012.JPG|thumb|Mulligan (2012)]] Mulligan is married to [[Marcus Mumford]], the lead singer of [[Mumford & Sons]]. They were childhood pen pals who lost touch and reconnected as adults.{{cite web|author=Perpetua, Matthew|title=Marcus Mumford Gets Engaged to Carey Mulligan|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/marcus-mumford-gets-engaged-to-carey-mulligan-20110804 |publisher=Rolling Stone|date=4 August 2011}}{{cite web|author=Marcus, Stephanie|title=Carey Mulligan Marries Marcus Mumford: Actress Weds Musician In England |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/04/21/carey-mulligan-marries-marries-marcus-mumford-in-england_n_1442914.html|publisher=Huffington Post|date=21 April 2012}} A few weeks after wrapping production on the film ''[[Inside Llewyn Davis]]'', in which they were both involved, they married on 21 April 2012.{{cite web|last=Hughes|first=Hilary|title=T Bone Burnett on the Making of Inside Llewyn Davis|url=http://www.esquire.com/blogs/culture/t-bone-burnett-interview|work=Esquire|publisher=Hearst Communications| date=20 November 2013}} They have a daughter, Evelyn Grace, born in September 2015, and a son, Wilfred, born in August 2017.{{cite news|title=Carey Mulligan Is Pregnant, Expecting Her First Child With Marcus Mumford|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-moms/news/carey-mulligan-pregnant-expecting-first-child-with-marcus-mumford-201586|accessdate=26 June 2015|publisher=US Magazine|date=8 June 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://ca.eonline.com/news/705971/carey-mulligan-reveals-her-daughter-s-name-just-weeks-after-welcoming-a-baby-girl-with-marcus-mumford|title=Carey Mulligan Reveals Her Daughter's Name Just Weeks After Welcoming Baby}} She has an older brother, Owain, who was formerly a Captain in the [[British Army]]. He served in both Iraq and Afghanistan.Nicholl, Katie [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2086781/Carey-Mulligans-brother-Owain-heads-Afghanistan.html "Carey's Mulligan's Brother Owain Heads to Afghanistan"] ''Daily Mail''Jonathan Ross Show, 15 November 2014 Series 7 Episode 5 ITV; Mulligan states that her brother was formerly in the army ==Philanthropy== Aside from acting, Mulligan was among the actresses who took part in the Safe Project—each was photographed in the place she feels safest—for a 2010 series to raise awareness of [[sex trafficking]].{{cite web |url=http://www.elleuk.com/news/fashion-news/black-lace-benefit-for-the-safe-project/(gid)/698928 |title=Black Lace Benefit for the Safe Project |work=Elle |publisher=[[Hachette Filipacchi Media]] |author=Cronin, Emily |date=24 November 2010 |accessdate=21 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004151935/http://www.elleuk.com/news/fashion-news/black-lace-benefit-for-the-safe-project/%28gid%29/698928 |archivedate=4 October 2011 |df=dmy }} She donated the [[Vionnet]] gown she wore at the [[2010 BAFTAs]] to the Curiosity Shop, which sells its donations to raise money for charity.{{cite web |url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/daily/100510-carey-mulligan-sells-vionnet-dress-.aspx |title=Caring Carey |work=Vogue UK |author=Milligan, Lauren |date=10 May 2010 |accessdate=10 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110612022514/http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/daily/100510-carey-mulligan-sells-vionnet-dress-.aspx |archivedate=12 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Mulligan became the ambassador of the [[Alzheimer's Society]] in 2012, with the goal of raising awareness and research funding for Alzheimers and dementia. Her grandmother lives with Alzheimer's disease and no longer recognises her.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-18115205 |title=Carey Mulligan supports bid to raise dementia awareness |work=BBC News |author=Brimelow, Adam |date=21 May 2012 |accessdate=21 December 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://www.alzheimers.org.uk/site/scripts/news_article.php?newsID=1203 |title=Actress Carey Mulligan to put spotlight on dementia as new Ambassador for Alzheimer's Society |work=Alzheimer's Society |author=Staff |date=21 May 2012 |accessdate=21 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121028062154/http://alzheimers.org.uk/site/scripts/news_article.php?newsID=1203 |archivedate=28 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }} She helped host and participated in the 2012 Alzheimer's Society ''Memory Walk'' and was one of the sponsored Alzheimer's Society runners in the 2013 Nike ''Run to the Beat'' half-marathon in London.{{cite web|last=Staff|title=Carey Mulligan to 'Run to the Beat' for Alzheimer's Society|url=http://www.alzheimers.org.uk/site/scripts/news_article.php?newsID=1754|work=Alzheimer's Society|date=16 August 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131012062639/http://www.alzheimers.org.uk/site/scripts/news_article.php?newsID=1754|archivedate=12 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|last=Staff|title=Carey Mulligan to step out to fight dementia in London|url=http://www.alzheimers.org.uk/site/scripts/news_article.php?newsID=1331|work=Alzheimer's Society|date=21 September 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130127063959/http://www.alzheimers.org.uk/site/scripts/news_article.php?newsID=1331|archivedate=27 January 2013|df=dmy-all}} In 2014, Mulligan became an ambassador for the charity [[War Child (charity)|War Child]]; in 2014 she visited the [[Democratic Republic of Congo]] in this role.{{cite web|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/showbiz/515609/Carey-Mulligan-named-War-Child-Global-Ambassador|title=Carey Mulligan named War Child Global Ambassador|date=26 September 2014|publisher=}}[http://www.warchild.org.uk/news/carey-mulligan-joins-war-child War Child: Carey Mulligan joins War Child] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141019003648/http://www.warchild.org.uk/news/carey-mulligan-joins-war-child |date=19 October 2014 }} ==Filmography== ===Cinema=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! [[File:MET DP123358.jpg|thumb|The Dream of Queen Maya (the Buddha's Conception) ca. 2nd century.[[Metropolitan Museum of Art ]]]] [[File:Kalpasutra Queen Trishalas dream.jpg|thumb|Kalpasutra Queen Trishalas dream]] '''Conception dreams''' are [[dream]]s that are said to foretell the [[Fertilisation|conception]] or [[birth]] of a child, dreamt by the future mother or people close to her. The belief that a dream will foretell a baby's birth originates from Ancient [[India]]<ref>Beal, Samuel, transl. (1875), The romantic legend of Sâkya Buddha (Abhiniṣkramaṇa Sūtra), London: Trübner</ref><ref>https://archive.org/details/romanticlegendof00ahbi</ref><ref>The Mahāvastu, Sacred Books of the Buddhists, 2, London: Luzac & Co</ref><ref>https://archive.org/details/sacredbooksofbud18londuoft</ref><ref>Dreaming in the Lotus: Buddhist Dream Narrative, Imagery, and Practice By Serinity Young</ref> and is found in some Asian countries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asdreams.org/2003/abstracts/nah-ree_doh.htm|title=Psychological significance of Korean women's "conception dreams"}}</ref>
==In India== Ancient India believes that conception dream predicts the child character. [[Maya (mother of the Buddha)]] dreamt that a white elephant with six white tusks entered her right side.<ref>Beal, Samuel, transl. (1875), The romantic legend of Sâkya Buddha (Abhiniṣkramaṇa Sūtra), London: Trübner</ref><ref>https://archive.org/details/romanticlegendof00ahbi</ref><ref>The Mahāvastu, Sacred Books of the Buddhists, 2, London: Luzac & Co</ref><ref>https://archive.org/details/sacredbooksofbud18londuoft</ref>
In [[Jainism]] dreams are connected with the births of [[Tirthankara]]s and the other prominent people including ''[[chakravarti]]'', ''[[Balabhadra]]''s and ''Vāsudevas''. They are 63 in total and called ''[[Shalakapurusha]]''. Their mothers see a certain number of dreams on conception of their soul in womb. They are described in the great detail in [[Kalpa Sūtra|Kalpasutra]].<ref>http://www.jainpedia.org/nc/themes/principles/holy-symbols/dreams.html?sword_list%5B0%5D=dreams&cHash=33eba476582356cda9587de0d285a3b9Balbir, Nalini. "Article: Dreams". Institute of Jainology. jainpedia.org. pp. 1–4.</ref><ref>"http://www.herenow4u.net/index.php?id=74790The Dreams of Queen Trishala". www.herenow4u.net. 2010-09-22.</ref> 12th century Jain monk [[Hemchandracharya]] described and interpreted them in detail in ''Trishashthishalakapurush''. ''Avashyak-niryukti'', an early verse-commentary in Prakrit, explains relation of names of some [[Tirthankara]]s and these dreams.<ref>http://www.jainpedia.org/nc/themes/principles/holy-symbols/dreams.html?sword_list%5B0%5D=dreams&cHash=33eba476582356cda9587de0d285a3b9Balbir, Nalini. "Article: Dreams". Institute of Jainology. jainpedia.org. pp. 1–4.</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |+Foretelling as per ''Kalpasutra'' |- ! Number of dreams !! What it foretells |- | 14 dreams || birth of a future ''Tirthankara'' or ''Chakravarti'' (universal monarch) |- | 7 of the 14 dreams || birth of a future Vāsudeva |- | 4 of the 14 dreams || birth of a future Baladeva |- | 1 of the 14 dreams || birth of a future Mandalika (king) |} {{main article|Auspicious dreams in Jainism}} [[Rathore]] ruler Simhaji's queen dreamt 3 lions before birth of his 3 son.<ref>Muhnot Nainsi Ki Khyat Khand-ii.Page:- 53-54.https://archive.org/details/in.ernet.dli.2015.308977</ref> [[Ramakrishna]] parents experienced supernatural incidents and visions before his birth. In [[Gaya, India|Gaya]] his father Khudiram had a dream in which Lord Gadadhara (a form of [[Vishnu]]), said that he would be born as his son. Chandramani Devi is said to have had a vision of light entering her womb from Shiva's temple.{{sfn|Chatterjee|1993|pp=46–47}}{{sfn|Harding|1998|pp=243–244}} [[Nahusha]] mother Indumati had conception dream.<ref>Padma purana, shrishti khand, 104</ref> According to [[Dashakumaracharita]] Queen vasumati conceiving her first son hamsavahana, dreams that she has bathed in the water of all pilgrimages.while conceiving her second so Rajavahana she dreams that she swallowed the orb of universe.
==In Korea== In Korea conception dreams are known as 태몽(''taemong''). Many women in Korean culture report having such dreams themselves. Popular topics of the dreams include fruit (such apples, [[persimmon]]s, cherries, chestnuts), animals (tigers, snakes, goldfish), nature (rivers, rainbows), children and jewels. The dreamer might eat or take fruits, embrace animals, or interact with nature. The topic is believed to influence the [[gender]] or the future of the baby; for example, fruits are seen as a sign for a baby girl.
The person having the dream can be the mother herself, but close family members such as her mother or the husband can also have conception dreams instead of the mother.
Dreams are often considered to be [[omen]]s, and sometimes people will "buy" dreams from friends, if they feel it is a good omen or a good conception dream.
Accounts of conception dreams can be found in numerous old histories. One example is the conception dream of [[Kim Yushin]], from the 6th century [[Common Era|CE]], documented in the [[Samguk Sagi]].
==See also== *[[Trishala]] *[[Maya (mother of the Buddha)]] *[[Auspicious dreams in Jainism]] *[[Taegyo]] *[[Pregnancy]] *[[Prenatal development]] *[[Korean mythology]]
==References== <references />
[[Category:Korean culture]] [[Category:Indian culture]] [[Category:Folklore]] [[Category:Human pregnancy]]
