revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=November 2013}} {{notability|date=May 2010}} }}
'''National Art Hate Week''' ran from 13–20 July 2009 and was a largely imaginary and highly humorous event created by the "non-organisation" [[The British Art Resistance]]. British artists [[Billy Childish]], [[Jimmy Cauty]] and art collective [[Harry Adams (artist)|Harry Adams]] created the week to promote the public questioning the bureaucratic nature of the contemporary art world.
==About==
The artists involved questioned the ideas of permission, curatorship, commercialism and consensus within the art world using satirical and confrontational strategies. The campaign was largely imaginary and through its fictions sought to raise awareness of the wider public's opinions of the art world, as well as the way the art world was promoted and disseminated by those within it. According to The Guardian, "the point [was] to take a closer, more honest look at what's on show in public galleries and be unafraid to loathe it violently".<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2009/jul/13/national-art-hate-week-billy-childish Guardian article]</ref>
Music, posters, stamps, fake membership cards and graphic works were produced by the group as part of the week, including a limited edition 7" single with art work by [[Jamie Reid]] by a group made up of the artists involved under the name Silent Revolt.
The group failed to hand out propaganda leaflets outside the [[Tate Modern]] gallery in London on 15 July 2010.
==Future incarnations==
The movement has been altered to World Art Hate Day for 2010 and will occur on 21 June 2010.
==Releases== July 2009 "God Save Marcel Duchamp" [[Silent Revolt]] (band includes [[James Cauty]] and [[Billy Childish]] and [[Harry Adams (artist)|Harry Adams]])
==Notes and references== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2009/jul/13/national-art-hate-week-billy-childish National Art Hate Week needs you, The Guardian, 13 July 2009] *[http://art-for-a-change.com/blog/2009/07/art-hate-week.html Art Hate Week, Art For A Change, 14 July 2009] *[http://www.arthate.com/index.html Official Art Hate site] {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}}
[[Category:Arts in the United Kingdom]]

revision.comment: Wikify Shane Fenton and the Fentones
revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=March 2008}} '''Needle time''' was created in the [[United Kingdom]] by the [[Musicians' Union (UK)|Musicians' Union]] and [[Phonographic Performance Limited]] to restrict the amount of recorded music that could be transmitted by the [[BBC]] during the course of any 24-hour period. The number of hours per week allowed gradually increased over the years from below 30 hours in the 1950s. Until 1967{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}} the BBC was allowed to play only five hours per day of commercial gramophone records on the air. It continued to affect [[BBC Radio 1]], [[BBC Radio 2]] and the [[Independent Local Radio]] stations until 1988.
The result was that the BBC had to use "cover" versions of popular songs by groups such as [[Shane Fenton and the Fentones]] recorded at the BBC studios, or orchestral versions by one of the in-house orchestras, to fill in the hours.
The term "needle time" comes from the use (at the time) of gramophone records as the main source of recorded music, which were played on gramophone record players using a [[magnetic cartridge|gramophone needle]].
==Needle time notice== Unlike American records, British records at the time carried a warning message around the edge of the record label in the centre of the record itself to the effect that: "Unauthorised public performance or broadcasting of this record is strictly prohibited."
===Radio Luxembourg=== Although the record industry in [[UK|Britain]] wanted the public to buy its records, it had to give them some airtime so that the public could find out about their existence. To that end the record industry used the commercial nighttime signals from [[Radio Luxembourg (English)|Radio Luxembourg]] whose powerful AM signal could be heard in the [[United Kingdom|UK]]. The "208" shows on Luxembourg were mainly fifteen minutes to thirty minutes in length and presented under names such as the ''[[Decca Records]] Show'' or the ''[[Capitol Records]] Show''. These prerecorded programmes resembled what later became known as [[Infomercials]], because they normally only featured a little over half of the record, with heavy plugging for title, artist and label.
Because all the hours of transmission were booked up by the major record companies (EMI, Decca, Pye, Philips etc.) groups and artists had to sign to them to get any exposure. This was one of the driving forces for [[Ronan O'Rahilly]] and others to start the first pirate radio station to get exposure for artists he represented.
===The "pirate stations"=== Unlike the [[BBC]] or Radio Luxembourg, the offshore [[pirate radio]] stations of the 1960s operated not only outside the three-mile limit of [[territorial waters]], but also in a grey area of the law. Because the studios and transmitters were located on board the ships or offshore structures, the personnel on board were only under the authority of the captain of that ship or structure. In the case of ship stations such as [[Wonderful Radio London]] which introduced [[top 40]] radio to Britain, the ship was actually registered in a foreign country and therefore subject to the laws of that country, which of course did not recognize "needle time". [[Payola]] operated on several of these stations.
==See also== *[[IFPI]] - a history of attempts by the record industry to claim a separate right to ownership of recorded works.
[[Category:Music industry]] [[Category:Broadcast law]]

revision.comment: /* Authorship */
revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''On the Sublime''''' (Περì Ὕψους Perì Hýpsous) is a [[Roman Greece|Roman-era Greek]] work of [[literary criticism]] dated to the 1st century AD. Its author is unknown, but is conventionally referred to as '''Longinus''' ({{IPAc-en|l|ɒ|n|ˈ|dʒ|aɪ|n|ə|s}}; {{lang-grc|Λογγῖνος}} ''Longĩnos'') or '''Pseudo-Longinus'''. It is regarded as a classic work on [[aesthetics]] and the effects of good writing. The treatise highlights examples of good and bad writing from the previous millennium, focusing particularly on what may lead to the [[Sublime (philosophy)|sublime]].
The author's identity has been debated for centuries. The oldest surviving manuscript, from the 10th century, indicates the original author was named "Dionysius or Longinus", which was later misread as "Dionysius Longinus". Subsequent interpretations have attributed the work to [[Dionysius of Halicarnassus]] (1st century) or [[Cassius Longinus (philosopher)|Cassius Longinus]] (c. 213–273 AD), though neither is now widely accepted.
==Authorship == The author is unknown. In the 10th-century reference manuscript (Parisinus Graecus 2036), the heading reports "Dionysius or Longinus", an ascription by the medieval [[copyist]] that was misread as "by Dionysius Longinus." When the manuscript was being prepared for printed publication, the work was initially attributed to [[Cassius Longinus (philosopher)|Cassius Longinus]] (c. 213–273 AD). Since the correct translation includes the possibility of an author named "Dionysius", some have attributed the work to [[Dionysius of Halicarnassus]], a writer of the 1st century AD.<ref name="Grube">{{cite book|last=Grube|first=G.M.A|title=On Great Writing (On the Sublime) |publisher=The Liberal Arts Press|location=New York|year=1957|isbn=978-0-87220-080-7}}</ref> There remains the possibility that the work belongs to neither Cassius Longinus nor Dionysius of Halicarnassus, but, rather, some unknown author writing under the [[Roman Empire]], likely in the 1st century. The error does imply that when the [[codex]] was written, the trails of the real author were already lost. Neither author can be accepted as the actual writer of the treatise. Dionysius maintained ideas which are absolutely opposite to those written in the treatise; with Longinus, there are problems with chronology.
Among further names proposed, are Hermagoras (a rhetorician who lived in Rome during the 1st century AD), [[Aelius Theon]] (author of a work which had many ideas in common with those of ''On the Sublime''), and Pompeius Geminus (who was in epistolary conversation with Dionysius).
===Dionysius of Halicarnassus=== [[Dionysius of Halicarnassus]] wrote under Augustus, publishing a number of works. Dionysius is generally dismissed as the potential author of ''On the Sublime'', since the writing officially attributed to Dionysius differs from the work ''On the Sublime'' in style and thought.<ref name="Russell">{{cite book|last=Russell|first=Andrew Russell|title='Longinus' on the Sublime|publisher=Clarendon Press|year=1964}}</ref>
===Cassius Longinus=== Credited with writing a number of literary works, Longinus was disciple of [[Plotinus]], and considered "the most distinguished scholar of his day." He received his education at Alexandria and then went to Athens to teach. He later moved to Asia Minor, where he achieved the position of advisor to [[Zenobia]], the queen of [[Palmyra]].<ref name="search.proquest.com">Longinus. (1851, Jul 01). Robert Merry's Museum (1841-1851), 22, 179. Retrieved from http://search.proquest.com/docview/135926705</ref><ref name="Russell" /><ref>Longinus. 9 Vol. Detroit: The Gale Group Inc, 2004.</ref> Cassius is a dubious possibility for author of the treatise because he wrote in the 3rd century, and no literature later than the 1st century AD is mentioned (the latest is [[Cicero]], who died in 43 BC){{clarify|date=April 2017|Last citations are 1st C AD by Cicero who died 1st C BC?}} and the work is now usually dated to the early 1st century AD. The work ends with a dissertation on the decay of oratory, a typical subject for the time when authors such as [[Tacitus]], [[Petronius]] and [[Quintilian]], who also dealt with the subject, were alive. Cassius was executed by Aurelian, the Roman emperor who conquered Palmyra in 273 AD were on charges of conspiring against the Roman state. This was most likely because of what he had written for Queen Zenobia of Palmyra while she was still in power. Longinus is reported to have written answers for the Queen, which were used in response to Aurelian, the man who would soon rise to power as the Roman emperor.<ref name="search.proquest.com"/>
==Contents== ''On the Sublime'' is both a treatise on [[aesthetics]] and a work of literary criticism. It is written in an epistolary form and the final part, possibly dealing with public speaking, has been lost.
The treatise is dedicated to Posthumius Terentianus, a cultured Roman and public figure, though little else is known of him. ''On the Sublime'' is a compendium of literary exemplars, with about 50 authors spanning 1,000 years mentioned or quoted.<ref name="Roberts">{{cite book|last=Roberts|first=William Rhys|title=Longinus on the Sublime|year=1899}}</ref> Along with the expected examples from [[Homer]] and other figures of Greek culture, Longinus refers to a passage from ''[[Book of Genesis|Genesis]]'', which is quite unusual for the 1st century:
{{quote|A similar effect was achieved by the lawgiver of the Jews—no mean genius, for he both understood and gave expression to the power of the divinity as it deserved—when he wrote at the very beginning of his laws, and I quote his words: "God said,"—what was it?—"Let there be light, and there was. Let there be earth, and there was."|''On the Sublime'' 9.9}}
Given his positive reference to Genesis, Longinus has been assumed to be either a Hellenized Jew or readily familiar with the Jewish culture.<ref name="Leitch">{{cite book|last=Leitch|first=Vincent B.|title=The Norton Anthology of Theory and Criticism|publisher=Norton|year=2001|pages=135–154|isbn=978-0-393-97429-4}}</ref> As such, Longinus emphasizes that, to be a truly great writer, authors must have "moral excellence".<ref name="Russell" /> In fact, critics speculate that Longinus avoided publication in the ancient world "either by modesty or by prudential motives".<ref name="Roberts" /> Moreover, Longinus stresses that transgressive writers are not necessarily shameless fools, even if they take literary risks that seem "bold, lawless, and original".<ref name="Russell" /> As for social subjectivity, Longinus acknowledges that complete liberty promotes spirit and hope; according to Longinus, "never did a slave become an orator".<ref name="Blair">{{cite book|last=Blair|first=Hugh |author2=Abraham Mills |title=From Lectures on Rhetoric and Belles Lettres|publisher=T. Zell|year=1866|edition=2nd|pages=950–979}}</ref> On the other hand, too much luxury and wealth leads to a decay in eloquence—eloquence being the goal of the [[sublimity|sublime]] writer.<ref name="Roberts" />
===The sublime=== Longinus critically applauds and condemns certain literary works as examples of good or bad styles of writing.<ref name="Roberts" /> Longinus ultimately promotes an "elevation of style"<ref name="Roberts" /> and an essence of "simplicity".<ref name="Brody">{{cite book|last=Brody|first=Jules|title=Boileau and Longinus|publisher=E. Droz|year=1958}}</ref> To quote this famous author, "the first and most important source of sublimity [is] the power of forming great conceptions."<ref name="Brody" /> The concept of the [[sublimity|sublime]] is generally accepted to refer to a style of writing that elevates itself "above the ordinary". Finally, Longinus sets out five sources of sublimity: "great thoughts, strong emotions, certain figures of thought and speech, noble diction, and dignified word arrangement".<ref name="Leitch" />
The effects of the Sublime are: loss of rationality, an alienation leading to identification with the creative process of the artist and a deep emotion mixed in pleasure and exaltation. An example of sublime (which the author quotes in the work) is a poem by [[Sappho]], the so-called ''Ode to Jealousy'', defined as a "Sublime ode". A writer's goal is not so much to express empty feelings, but to arouse emotion in her audience.<ref name="Brody" />
In the treatise, the author asserts that "the Sublime leads the listeners not to persuasion, but to ecstasy: for what is wonderful always goes together with a sense of dismay, and prevails over what is only convincing or delightful, since persuasion, as a rule, is within everyone's grasp: whereas, the Sublime, giving to speech an invincible power and [an invincible] strength, rises above every listener".<ref>''On the Sublime'' 1.4.</ref>
According to this statement, one could think that the sublime, for Longinus, was only a moment of evasion from reality. But on the contrary, he thought that literature could model a soul, and that a soul could pour itself out into a work of art. In this way the treatise becomes not only a text of literary inquiry, but also one of ethical dissertation, since the Sublime becomes the product of a ''great soul'' ({{lang|grc|μεγαλοφροσύνης ἀπήχημα}}, ''megalophrosunēs apēchēma''). The sources of the Sublime are of two kinds: inborn sources ("aspiration to vigorous concepts" and "strong and enthusiastic passion") and acquirable sources (rhetorical devices, choice of the right lexicon, and "dignified and high composition").<ref name="Brody" />
===Decay of rhetoric=== The author speaks also about the decay of oratory, as arising not only from absence of personal freedom but also from the corruption of morals, which together destroy that high spirit which generates the Sublime. Thus the treatise is clearly centred in the burning controversy which raged in the 1st century AD in Latin literature. If [[Petronius]] pointed out excess of rhetoric and the pompous, unnatural techniques of the schools of eloquence as the causes of decay, [[Tacitus]] was nearer to Longinus in thinking<ref name="Grube"/> that the root of this decadence was the establishment of Princedom, or Empire, which, though it brought stability and peace, also gave rise to censorship and brought an end to freedom of speech. Thus oratory became merely an exercise in style.
===Misleading translations and lost data=== Translators have been unable to clearly interpret the text, including the title itself. The "sublime" in the title has been translated in various ways, to include senses of elevation and excellent style. The word [[sublimity|sublime]], argues Rhys Roberts, is misleading, since Longinus' objective broadly concerns "the essentials of a noble and impressive style" than anything more narrow and specific. Moreover, about one-third of the treatise is missing;<ref name="Roberts" /> Longinus' segment on similes, for instance, has only a few words remaining.<ref name="Russell" /> Matters are further complicated in realizing that ancient writers, Longinus' contemporaries, do not quote or mention the treatise in any way.<ref name="Roberts" />
===Limitations of the writing=== Despite Longinus' critical acclaim, his writing is far from perfect. Longinus' occasional enthusiasm becomes "carried away" and creates some confusion as to the meaning of his text. Furthermore, 18th-century critic [[Edward Burnaby Greene]] finds Longinus, at times, to be "too refined".<ref name="Greene" /> Greene also claims that Longinus' focus on hyperbolical descriptions is "particularly weak, and misapplied."<ref name="Grube" /> Occasionally, Longinus also falls into a sort of "tediousness" in treating his subjects.<ref name="Roberts" /> The treatise is also limited in its concentration on spiritual transcendence and lack of focus on the way in which language structures determine the feelings and thoughts of writers.<ref name="Leitch" /> Finally, Longinus' treatise is difficult to explain in an academic setting, given the difficulty of the text and lack of "practical rules of a teachable kind."<ref name="Russell" />
===Writing style and rhetoric=== Despite its faults, the treatise remains critically successful because of its "noble tone," "apt precepts," "judicious attitude," and "historical interests".<ref name="Roberts" /> One of the reasons why it is so unlikely that known ancient critics wrote ''On the Sublime'' is because the treatise is composed so differently from any other literary work. Since Longinus' rhetorical formula avoids dominating his work, the literature remains "personal and fresh," unique in its originality. Longinus rebels against the popular rhetoric of the time by implicitly attacking ancient theory in its focus on a detailed criticism of words, metaphors, and figures. More explicitly, in refusing to judge tropes as entities unto themselves, Longinus promotes the appreciation of literary devices as they relate to passages as a whole.<ref name="Grube" /> Essentially, Longinus, rare for a critic of his time, focuses more on "greatness of style" than "technical rules."<ref name="Roberts" /> Despite his criticism of ancient texts, Longinus remains a "master of candor and good-nature".<ref name="Greene">{{cite book|last=Greene|first=Edward Burnaby|title=Critical Essays: 1770|year=1973|isbn=978-0-85417-911-4}}</ref> Moreover, the author invents striking images and metaphors, writing almost lyrically at times.<ref name="Grube" /> In general, Longinus appreciates, and makes use of, simple diction and bold images.<ref name="Russell" />
As far as the language is concerned, the work is certainly a unicum because it is a blend of expressions of the Hellenistic [[Koine Greek]] to which are added elevated constructions, technical expressions, metaphors, classic and rare forms which produce a literary pastiche at the borders of linguistic experimentation.
===Influences=== In reading ''On the Sublime'', critics have determined that the ancient philosopher and writer Plato is a "great hero" to Longinus.<ref name="Russell" /> Not only does Longinus come to Plato's defense, but he also attempts to raise his literary standing in opposition to current criticisms. Another influence on the treatise can be found in Longinus' rhetorical figures, which draw from theories by a 1st-century BC writer, [[Caecilius of Calacte]].<ref name="Roberts" />
==Historical criticism and use of ''On the Sublime''== *10th century - The original treatise, before translation, is copied into a medieval manuscript and attributed to "Dionysius or Longinus."<ref name="Leitch" /> *13th century - A Byzantine rhetorician makes obscure references to what may be Longinus' text.<ref name="Grube" /> *16th century - The treatise is ignored by scholars until it is published by [[Francis Robortello]] in [[Basel]], in 1554, and Niccolò da Falgano, in 1560.<ref name="Leitch" /> The original work is attributed to "Dionysius Longinus" and most European countries receive translations of the treatise.<ref name="Roberts" /> *17th century - Sublime effects become a desired end of much [[Baroque]] art and literature, and the rediscovered work of "Longinus" goes through half a dozen editions in the 17th century. It is [[Nicolas Boileau-Despréaux|Boileau]]'s 1674 translation of the treatise into French that really starts its career in the history of criticism. Despite its popularity, some critics claim that the treatise was too "primitive" to be truly understood by a "too civilized" 17th-century audience. *18th century - [[William Smith (scholar)|William Smith's]] 1739 translation of ''Longinus on the Sublime'' established the translator and once more brought the work into prominence. Longinus' text reaches its height in popularity.<ref name="Grube" /> In England, critics esteem Longinus' principles of composition and balance second only to [[Aristotle]]'s ''[[Poetics (Aristotle)|Poetics]]''. [[Edmund Burke]]'s ''[[A Philosophical Enquiry into the Origin of Our Ideas of the Sublime and Beautiful]]'' and Immanuel Kant's ''Critique of the Power of Judgment''<ref>Clewis, Robert R. (2009). ''The Kantian Sublime and the Revelation of Freedom''. Cambridge University Press, pp. 12-13.</ref> owe a debt to Longinus' concept of the [[sublimity|sublime]], and the category passes into intellectual discourse. As "Longinus" says, "The effect of elevated language upon an audience is not persuasion but transport," a fitting sentiment for Romantic thinkers and writers who reach beyond logic, to the wellsprings of the Sublime. At the same time, the Romantics gain some contempt for Longinus, given his association with the "rules" of classical poets. Such contempt is ironic, given the widespread influence of Longinus on the shaping of 18th-century criticism.<ref name="Russell" /> *19th century - Early in the 19th century, doubts arise to the authorship of the treatise. Thanks to Italian scholar Amati, Cassius Longinus is no longer assumed to be the writer of ''On the Sublime''.<ref name="Roberts" /> Simultaneously, the critical popularity of Longinus' work diminishes greatly; though the work is still in use by scholars, it is rarely quoted. Despite the lack of public enthusiasm, editions and translations of ''On the Sublime'' are published at the end of the century.<ref name="Grube" /> *20th century - Although the text is still little quoted, it maintains its status, apart from Aristotle's ''Poetics'', as "the most delightful of all the critical works of classical antiquity."<ref name="Grube" /> Also see [[Neil Hertz]]'s essay on Longinus in his book, ''The End of the Line.'' Hertz is in part responding to [[Thomas Weiskel]]'s book ''The Romantic Sublime'', probably the most influential recent account of British and German Romantic attitudes towards the Sublime of both Burke and Longinus.<ref name="Hertz">{{cite book|last=Hertz|first=Neil|title=The End of the Line|publisher=Columbia University Press|year=1985|isbn=978-0-231-05708-0}}</ref><ref name="Weiskel">{{cite book|last=Thomas|first=Weiskel|author2=Portia Williams Weiskel |title=The Romantic Sublime|publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press|year=1976|isbn=978-0-8018-1770-0}}</ref> Laura Quinney treats the attractions grim demystification in analyzes of Longinus, particularly Weiskel's.<ref name="Quinney2">{{cite book|last=Quinney|first=Laura|title=Weiskel's Sublime and the Impasse of Knowledge}}</ref> Jonathan Culler has an appreciation of Hertz on Longinus in "The Hertzian Sublime."<ref name="Culler">{{cite journal|last=Culler|first=Jonathan|title=The Hertzian sublime|journal=[[MLN]]|volume=120|issue=5|pages=969–985|doi=10.1353/mln.2006.0007|year=2005}}</ref> [[Anne Carson]] and [[Louis Marin (philosopher)|Louis Marin]] have occasion to discuss Longinus as well and [[Harold Bloom]] and William J. Kennedy have significant accounts of his work. [[William Carlos Williams]] also uses three lines from the work as an epigraph to the Prologue to [[Kora in Hell]].<ref name="Carson">{{cite book|last=Carson|first=Anne|title=Conjunctions|year=2001|pages=96–104|chapter=Foam: (Essay with Rhapsody) On the Sublime in Longinus and Antonioni}}</ref><ref name="Marin">{{cite book|last=Marin|first=Louis|author2=Nicolas Poussin |author3=Catherine Porter |title=The Sublime Poussin|publisher=Stanford University Press|year=1999|isbn=978-0-8047-3477-6}}</ref><ref name="Kennedy">{{cite book|last=Kennedy|first=William J.|author2=Brenda Deen Schildgen |title=The Rhetoric Canon|publisher=Wayne State University Press|year=1997|chapter=Interest in the Canon: Kant in the Context of Longinus and Adorno|isbn=978-0-8143-2632-9}}</ref>
German film director [[Werner Herzog]] claims to have an affinity with the work of Longinus, in a talk entitled "On the Absolute, the Sublime and Ecstatic Truth", presented in Milan. Herzog says that he thinks of Longinus as a good friend and considers that Longinus's notions of illumination has a parallel in some moments in his films. He quotes from Longinus: "For our soul is raised out of nature through the truly sublime, sways with high spirits, and is filled with proud joy, as if itself had created what it hears."
==Notes== {{Reflist|2}}
==Further reading== *{{cite book|last=Bloom|first=Harold|title=Agon: Towards a Theory of Revisionism|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1983|isbn=978-0-19-503354-0}} *{{cite book|last=Doran|first=Robert|title=The Theory of the Sublime from Longinus to Kant|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2015}} *{{cite journal|last=Ferguson|first=Frances|date=Winter 1985|title=A Commentary on Suzanne Guerlac's 'Longinus and the Subject of the Sublime'|journal=[[New Literary History]]|volume=16|issue=2|pages=291–297|doi=10.2307/468748|publisher=The Johns Hopkins University Press|jstor=468748}}* *{{cite book|last=Quinney|first=Laura, foreword by Harold Bloom|title=Literary Power and the Criteria of Truth|publisher=University Press of Florida|year=1995|isbn=978-0-8130-1345-9}} * Martin Fritz, ''Vom Erhabenen. Der Traktat 'Peri Hypsous' und seine ästhetisch-religiöse Renaissance im 18. Jahrhundert'' (Tübingen, Mohr Siebeck, 2011).
==External links== {{wikisource|On the Sublime}} {{wikiquote|Longinus}} *[http://hodoi.fltr.ucl.ac.be/concordances/longin_du_sublime/lecture/default.htm Text of ''On the Sublime] (Ancient Greek, with Boileau's 1674 French translation in parallel) *[http://www.slu.edu/colleges/AS/languages/classical/latin/tchmat/pedagogy/latinitas/lgi/lgi.html Text of ''On the Sublime'' (Zachary Pearce's Latin translation from 1762)] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20040303175711/http://www.scholars.nus.edu.sg/landow/victorian/philosophy/sublime/longinus.html Dr George P. Landow, "Longinus" "On Great Writing" and the 18th-century Sublime"] * {{Gutenberg author |id=Longinus | name=Longinus}} * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Longinus}} * ''Rhetores Graeci'', L. Spengel (ed.), Lipsiae, sumptibus et typis B. G. Teubneri, 1853, [https://archive.org/stream/rhetoresgraeci00spen#page/242/mode/2up vol. 1 pp. 243-296].
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Longinus}} [[Category:Ancient Greek rhetoricians]] [[Category:Literary theorists]] [[Category:Books of literary criticism]] [[Category:Platonism]] [[Category:Greek literature (post-classical)]] [[Category:Texts in Koine Greek]] [[Category:Literary critics]] [[Category:Aesthetics literature]] [[Category:Roman philosophical literature]]
[[ar:لونجينوس]]

revision.comment: Updating URL format for [[The New York Times]] archives
revision.text:
The '''expansive force of [[rust]]ing''', which may be called '''oxide jacking''' or '''rust burst''', is a phenomenon that can cause damage to structures made of stone, masonry, concrete or ceramics, and reinforced with metal components. A definition is "the displacement of building elements due to the expansion of iron and steel products as the metal rusts and becomes iron oxide".<ref>{{cite book | last = Bucher | first = Ward | title = Dictionary of Building Preservation | publisher = [[John Wiley & Sons|Wiley Interscience]] | year = 1996 | location = [[New York City|New York]] | page = 319 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=1QA-MuOcjN4C&pg=PA319 | isbn = 0-471-14413-4 | jfm = }}</ref> Corrosion of other metals such as aluminum can also cause oxide jacking.
==Physical process==
According to [[Metallurgy|metallurgist]] Jack Harris, "Oxidation is usually accompanied by a net expansion so that when it occurs in a confined space stresses are generated in the metal component itself or in any surrounding medium such as stone or cement. So much energy is released by oxidation that the stresses generated are of sufficient magnitude to deform or fracture all known materials."<ref name=Harris2>{{cite journal | last = Harris | first = J.E. | title = Oxidation induced deformation and fracture | journal = Advances in Fracture Research | pages = 3791–811 | publisher = [[Pergamon Press]] | location = [[Oxford]] | year = 1984 | url = http://www.bcin.ca/Interface/openbcin.cgi?submit=submit&Chinkey=96347# | accessdate = January 2, 2012}}</ref>
As early as 1915, it was recognized that certain modern metal alloys are more susceptible to excessive [[Oxidation state|oxidation]] when subjected to [[weathering]] than other metals. At that time, there was a trend to replace [[wrought iron]] fasteners with [[Carbon steel#Mild and low carbon steel|mild steel]] equivalents, which were less expensive. Unexpectedly, the mild steel fasteners failed in real world use much more quickly than anticipated, leading to a return to use of wrought iron in certain applications where length of service was important.<ref>{{cite news | title = Rust and Mild Steel | newspaper = [[New York Times]] | date = July 18, 1915 | url = https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1915/07/18/104015289.pdf | accessdate = January 2, 2012}}</ref>
==Damage to notable buildings== [[File:Horses of Basilica San Marco bright.jpg|right|thumb|These original Horses of Saint Mark have been relocated indoors, and replaced by replicas.]] [[File:Land Title Building.JPG|right|thumb|The cornice at the top of the Land Title Building was damaged by oxide jacking.]] [[File:Mies van der Rohe photo Farnsworth House Plano USA 9.jpg|right|thumb|Oxide jacking damage was discovered after a flood at the Farnsworth House.]] [[File:Herbst oxide jacking.jpg|thumb|Herbst oxide jacking|Oxide jacking has caused concrete spalling on walls of the Herbst Pavilion at [[Fort Mason Center]] in San Francisco]]
In a 1987 article in ''[[New Scientist]]'', Jack Harris reported that oxide jacking has caused significant damage to many historic structures in the United Kingdom, including [[St Paul's Cathedral]], the [[British Museum]] and the [[Albert Memorial]] in London, [[Gloucester Cathedral]], [[List of buildings in King's Lynn#St Margaret's Church|St. Margaret's Church]] in [[King's Lynn]], [[Winchester Cathedral]], and [[Blackburn Cathedral]].<ref name=Harris>{{cite news | last = Harris | first = Jack | title = The Expanding Problem of Rust: Try to solve one problem and you often create another. Rusting can arise this way, as is clear from edifices ancient and modern | newspaper = [[New Scientist]] | location = [[London]] | pages = 44–47 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=TdHKaVQMVBYC&pg=PA44 | accessdate = January 2, 2012}}</ref>
Harris also wrote that oxide jacking also damaged the ancient [[Horses of Saint Mark]] on the exterior of [[St. Mark's Basilica]] in [[Venice]]. Expansive rusting of iron and steel bolts and reinforcements affected the structural integrity of the copper horse sculptures, which were relocated indoors and replaced with replicas. Poorly-designed early 20th-century renovations also led to oxide jacking damage to the [[Acropolis of Athens]].<ref name=Harris/>
In the United States, rusting of iron pegs inserted into holes in the stone entrance stair in order to support [[handrails]] resulted in cracking of the steps at the [[Basilica of the Sacred Heart, Notre Dame|Basilica of the Sacred Heart]] in [[Notre Dame, Indiana]].<ref>{{cite book | last = Winkler | first = Erhard M. | title = Stone in Architecture: Properties, Durability | publisher = [[Springer-Verlag]] | edition = 3rd | year = 1997 | location = [[Berlin]] | page = 239 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=u9zt12_gE-AC&pg=PA239 | isbn = 3-540-57626-6 | jfm = }}</ref>
Oxide jacking damaged the [[terra cotta]] [[cornice]] on the [[Land Title Building]] in [[Philadelphia]], designed in 1897 and expanded in 1902 by pioneer skyscraper architect [[Daniel Burnham]].<ref name=Tech/> The Land Title complex, with its two interconnected towers, is on the [[National Register of Historic Places]]. By 1922, experts on architectural terra cotta were warning that the rusting of embedded iron fasteners could cause decorative building components to fail.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Hill | first = C.W. | title = Terra Cotta Problems Suggested for Discussion and Investigation | journal = Journal of the American Ceramic Society | volume = 5 | issue = 10 | pages = 732–38 | publisher = [[American Ceramic Society]] | location = [[Easton, Pennsylvania]] | date = October 1922 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=6tPNAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA738 | accessdate = January 2, 2012 | doi=10.1111/j.1151-2916.1922.tb17607.x}}</ref> This 1902 cornice is nearly {{convert|9|ft|m}} high, projects {{convert|7|ft|m}} from the facade of the building and is {{convert|465|ft|m}} long. The cornice was stabilized, steel anchors subject to rusting were replaced with new stainless steel anchors, and the cornice was completely renovated. The project was completed in 1991.<ref name=Tech>{{cite news | last = Levine | first = Jeffrey S. |author2=Donna Ann Harris | title = Stabilization and Repair of a Historic Terra Cotta Cornice | newspaper = Preservation Tech Notes | location = [[Washington, DC]] | publisher = [[National Park Service]] | date = September 1991 | accessdate = January 2, 2012}}</ref>
Flooding in 2007 damaged the modernist [[Farnsworth House]] in [[Plano, Illinois]], designed in 1945 by [[Ludwig Mies van der Rohe]], and now owned by the [[National Trust for Historic Preservation]]. Among the damage discovered by an architect inspecting the house in 2007 was oxide jacking at the corners of the house's steel framework.<ref>{{cite web | last = Campagna | first = Barbara A. | title = Rescuing an Icon - Mies van der Rohe's Farnsworth House | work = Cities and Memory | date = August 25, 2007 | url = http://bcampagna39.blogspot.com/2007/08/rescuing-icon.html | accessdate = January 2, 2012}}</ref> The house flooded again in 2008.
==Damage to reinforced concrete bridges and buildings==
Structures built of [[concrete]] and reinforced with metal [[rebar]] are also subject to damage by oxide jacking. Expansion of corroded rebar causes [[spall]]ing of the concrete. Structures exposed to a marine environment, or where [[Sodium chloride#Road salt|salt]] is used for [[Snow removal#De-icing and anti-icing|de-icing]] purposes, are especially susceptible to this type of damage.<ref name=Harris/>
Research in the 1960s showed that 22% of concrete bridge decks in [[Pennsylvania]] showed signs of spalling due to oxide jacking within four years of construction. Oxide jacking caused widespread damage to concrete [[council houses]] built in the United Kingdom in the post World War II era.<ref name=Harris/>
According to an expert in the field, the problem resulted in "intensive worldwide research into the causes and repair of reinforcement corrosion, which in turn led to a vast output of research papers, conferences and publications on the subject."<ref>{{cite book | last = Pullar-Strecker | first = Peter | authorlink = | title = Concrete reinforcement corrosion: from assessment to repair decisions | publisher = Thomas Telford Publishing | series = | volume = | edition = | year = 2002 | location = [[London]] | pages = | language = | url = https://books.google.com/?id=X2okF77ltAEC&pg=PA15&dq=concrete+spalling+corrosion#v=onepage&q=concrete%20spalling%20corrosion&f=false | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-7277-3182-1 | mr = | zbl = | jfm = }}</ref>
==Damage to stone countertops== [[Countertop]] components fabricated out of [[granite]] and other natural stones are sometimes reinforced with metal rods inserted into grooves cut into the underside of the stone, and bonded in place with various resins. This procedure is called "rodding" by countertop fabricators. Most commonly, these rods will be placed near [[sink]] cutouts to prevent cracking of the brittle stone countertop during transportation and installation.<ref>{{cite news | last = Padden | first = Kevin M. | title = Rodding: Is It Right For Me? | newspaper = Surface Fabrication | publisher = [[Cygnus Business Media]] | date = April 2009 | url = http://www.surfacefabrication.com/print/Surface-Fabrication/Rodding--Is-It-Right-For-Me/1$795 | accessdate = January 2, 2012}}</ref> Data published by the Marble Institute of America shows that this technique results in a 600% increase in the [[Deflection (engineering)|deflection]] strength of the component.<ref name=Beware>{{cite news | last = Heaphy | first = Jim |author2=James Heaphy | title = Beware of Countertop Failure Caused by Rust | newspaper = Kitchen & Bath Design News | location = [[Fort Atkinson, Wisconsin]] | publisher = [[Cygnus Business Media]] | date = January 2010 | url = http://www.forresidentialpros.com/article/10348301/beware-of-countertop-failure-caused-by-rust | accessdate = January 24, 2012}}</ref>
However, if a metal rod subject to [[Oxidation state|oxidation]] or other forms of [[corrosion]] is used, and moisture from a [[sink]] or [[Tap (valve)|faucet]] reaches the rod, oxide jacking can crack the countertop directly above the rod.<ref>{{cite news | last = Baldwin | first = Deborah | title = When solving a problem creates a new one | newspaper = [[This Old House|This Old House magazine]] | location = [[New York City]] | date = January 19, 2010 | url = http://hardwareaisle.thisoldhouse.com/2010/01/when-one-problem-creates-another-.html | accessdate = January 2, 2012}}</ref> [[Carbon steel#Mild and low carbon steel|Mild steel]] and some grades of [[aluminium]] rods are known to cause oxide jacking failures in granite countertops. Skilled stone repair professionals can disassemble the cracked stone, remove the metal rod, and reassemble the stone using various resins tinted to match the colors of the stone.<ref name=Beware/> This type of problem can be prevented by using reinforcing rods made of [[stainless steel]] or [[fiberglass]] in the rodding procedure.<ref name=Beware/>
==See also== * [[Ice jacking]] * [[Concrete degradation]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.pioneermasonry.com/resources/Oxide%20Jacking.pdf Water and Masonry Decay: Photos of damage to brick buildings caused by oxide jacking] *[http://www.exploratorium.edu/outdoor/#/exhibit/rust-wedge/ Outdoor Exploratorium at Fort Mason: Rust Wedge: A museum exhibit showing the expansive force of rusting steel] *[http://www.springerlink.com/content/x071158u71367j06/ Harris, J.E., Weathering of rock, corrosion of stone and rusting of iron, ''MECCANICA'', Volume 27, Number 3]
[[Category:Corrosion]] [[Category:Architecture]] [[Category:Industrial design]]

revision.comment: convert to short description template
revision.text:
{{short description|Medieval and post-medieval English financial documents}} {{Use British English|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox Medieval text | name = Pipe rolls | image = Image:Pipe roll 1194.jpg | caption = Extract from the 1194 pipe roll | date = 1130–1833 | provenance = English [[Exchequer]] | series = Pipe rolls | genre = Accounting documents | subject = Records of the audits of the English Exchequer | period covered = 1130–1833 }}
The '''Pipe rolls''', sometimes called the '''Great rolls''',<ref name=Brown54>Brown ''Governance'' pp. 54–56</ref> or the '''Great Rolls of the Pipe''', are a collection of financial records maintained by the English [[Exchequer]], or Treasury, and its successors. The earliest date from the 12th century, and the series extends, mostly complete, from then until 1833.<ref name=Chrimes62>Chrimes ''Administrative History'' pp. 62–63</ref> They form the oldest continuous series of records concerning English governance kept by the English, British and United Kingdom governments, covering a span of about 700 years. The early medieval ones are especially useful for historical study, as they are some of the earliest financial records available from the Middle Ages. A similar set of records was developed for Normandy, which was ruled by the English kings from 1066 to 1205, but the Norman Pipe rolls have not survived in a continuous series like the English.
They were the records of the yearly audits performed by the Exchequer of the accounts and payments presented to the Treasury by the sheriffs and other royal officials; and owed their name to the shape they took, as the various sheets were affixed to each other and then rolled into a tight roll, resembling a pipe, for storage. They record not only payments made to the government, but debts owed to the crown and disbursements made by royal officials. Although they recorded much of the royal income, they did not record all types of income, nor did they record all expenditures, so they are not strictly speaking a budget. The Pipe Roll Society, formed in 1883, has published the Pipe rolls up until 1224.
==Composition== The Pipe rolls are named after the "pipe" shape formed by the rolled up [[parchment]]s on which the records were originally written.<ref name=Coredon219/> There is no evidence to support the theory that they were named pipes for the fact that they "piped" the money into the Treasury, nor for the claim that they got their name from resembling a wine cask, or [[Butt (volume)|pipe]] of wine.<ref name=Lyon112/> They were occasionally referred to as the roll of the treasury, or the great roll of accounts, and the great roll of the pipe.<ref name=Lyon112/>
The Pipe rolls are the records of the audits of the [[High Sheriff|sheriffs]]' accounts, usually conducted at [[Michaelmas]] by the [[Exchequer]], or English treasury.<ref name=Warren73>Warren ''Governance'' pp. 73–74</ref> Until the [[Charter Roll|chancery records]] began in the reign of King [[John of England]], they were the only continuous set of records kept by the English government.<ref name=Chrimes62/> They are not a complete record of government and royal finances, however, as they do not record all sources of income, only the accounts of the sheriffs and a few other sources of income. Some of the payments that did not regularly fall under the Exchequer were occasionally recorded in a Pipe roll. Neither do the Pipe rolls record all payments made by the exchequer.<ref name=Chrimes62/> They were not created as a budget, nor were they strictly speaking records of receipts, but rather they are records of the audit of the accounts rendered.<ref name=RandS216>Richardson and Sayles ''Governance'' pp. 216–217</ref> Although the rolls use an [[Accountancy|accounting system]], it is not one that would be familiar to modern accountants; for instance until the end of the 12th century, no record was made of the total amount taken in by the sheriff of each [[shire]].<ref name=Chrimes62/> In their early form, they record all debts owed to the [[The Crown|Crown]], whether from [[Feudalism|feudal]] dues or from other sources. Because many debts to the king were allowed to be paid off in installments, it is necessary to search more than one set of rolls for a complete history of a debt.<ref name=Warren76>Warren ''Governance'' pp. 76–77</ref> If a debt was not paid off completely in one year, the remainder of the amount owed was transferred to the next year. They did not record the full amount of debts incurred in previous years, only what was paid that year and what was still owed.<ref name=Bartlett198>Bartlett ''England Under the Norman and Angevin Kings'' p. 198</ref> Besides the sheriffs, others who submitted accounts for the audit included some bailiffs of various honours, town officials, and the custodians of ecclesiastical and feudal estates.<ref name=Lyon262>Lyon ''Constitutional and Legal History'' p. 262</ref>
The earliest surviving Pipe roll, already in a mature form, dates from 1129–30,<ref name=HenryI26/>{{efn|The Pipe Roll of 31 Henry I is "the earliest surviving comprehensive account of royal income in European history" according to [[C. Warren Hollister]]<ref name=HenryI26>Hollister ''Henry I'' p. 26</ref>}} and the continuous series begins in 1155–56,<ref name=Coredon219>Coredon ''Dictionary of Medieval Terms'' p. 219</ref> and continued for almost seven hundred years.<ref name=Lyon112>Lyon ''Constitutional and Legal History'' pp. 112–113</ref>
Combined with the [[Domesday Book|Domesday Survey]], the Pipe rolls contributed to the centralisation of financial records by the [[Norman dynasty|Norman kings]] (reigned 1066–1154) of England that was ahead of contemporary Western European monarchies; the French, for instance, did not have an equivalent system of accounting until the 1190s.<ref name=Chibnall>Chibnall ''Anglo-Norman England'' p. 126</ref> The exact form of the records, kept in a roll instead of a book, was also unique to England,<ref name=Memory136>Clanchy ''Memory to Written Record'' p. 136</ref> although why England kept some of its administrative records in this form is unclear.<ref name=Clanchy141>Clanchy ''Memory to Written Record'' p. 141</ref> A set of Norman rolls, drafted differently, are extant in a few years for the reigns of Kings [[Henry II of England|Henry II]] (reigned 1154–1189) and [[Richard I of England|Richard I]] (reigned 1189–1199), who also ruled the [[Duchy of Normandy]] in France.<ref name=Mason139>Mason "Administration and Government" ''Companion to the Anglo-Norman World'' p. 139</ref><ref name=Mason150>Mason "Administration and Government" ''Companion to the Anglo-Norman World'' p. 150</ref> It is believed that the Norman rolls were started about the same time as the English, but due to lack of survival of the earlier Norman rolls, it is unclear exactly when they did start.<ref name=Lyon220>Lyon ''Constitutional and Legal History'' pp. 220–221</ref> An Irish Exchequer produced Irish Pipe rolls, and much like the English Pipe rolls, the earliest surviving Irish Pipe roll, that of 1212, does not appear to be the first produced.<ref name=Frame87>Frame ''Political Development'' p. 87</ref>
The ''Dialogus de Scaccario'' or ''[[Dialogue concerning the Exchequer]]'', written in about 1178, details the workings of the Exchequer and gives an early account of how the Pipe rolls were created.<ref name=Chrimes60/> The ''Dialogue'' was written by [[Richard FitzNeal]], the son of [[Nigel (Bishop of Ely)|Nigel of Ely]], who was [[Lord High Treasurer|Treasurer]] for both [[Henry I of England|Henry I]] and Henry II of England.<ref name=Warren73/> According to the ''Dialogue'', the Pipe rolls were the responsibility of the clerk of the Treasurer, who was called the [[Clerk of the Pipe]] and later the clerk of the pells.<ref name=Chrimes60>Chrimes ''Administrative History'' p. 60</ref> FitzNeal wrote his work to explain the inner workings of the Exchequer, and in it he lists a number of different types of rolls used by the Treasury. He also describes the creation of the Pipe rolls and how they are used.<ref name=Clanchy136>Clanchy ''From Memory to Written Record'' p. 136</ref> The ''Dialogue'' also states that the Pipe rolls, along with [[Domesday Book]] and other records, were kept in the treasury, because they were required for daily use by the Exchequer clerks.<ref name=Clanchy151>Clanchy ''From Memory to Written Record'' p. 151</ref>
The main source of income recorded on the Pipe rolls was the county farm, or income derived from lands held by the king.<ref name=Lyon164>Lyon ''Constitutional and Legal History'' p. 164</ref> Occasional sources of revenue, such as from vacant bishoprics or abbeys or other sources, were also recorded.<ref name=Enc266>Loyn (ed.) ''Middle Ages'' p. 266</ref> The payments were made both in coin, or in objects, such as spurs, lands, spices, or livestock.<ref name=Lyon163>Lyon ''Constitutional and Legal History'' p. 163</ref> The only surviving roll from Henry I's reign also records payments of [[danegeld|geld]], a form of land tax dating from [[History of Anglo-Saxon England|Anglo-Saxon times]],<ref name=Warren68>Warren ''Governance'' p. 68</ref> although after 1161 the Pipe rolls no longer record any payments of geld.<ref name=Warren146>Warren ''Governance'' p. 146</ref>{{efn|Whether geld was abolished in 1161 or later is a matter of debate among historians.<ref name=Warren146/>}} By 1166, the fines and other monetary income of the [[Assize Court|Assizes]], or royal courts, began to be recorded in the Pipe rolls.<ref name=Warren111>Warren ''Governance'' p. 111</ref><ref name=Coredon23>Coredon ''Dictionary of Medieval Terms'' p. 23</ref> [[Scutage]] payments, made by knights in lieu of military service, were also recorded in the Pipe rolls from the reign of Henry II on.<ref name=Hollister578>Hollister "Significance of Scutage Rates" ''English Historical Review'' p. 578</ref><ref name=Dict252>Coredon ''Dictionary'' p. 252</ref>{{efn|It is unclear if the recording of scutage in the Pipe rolls was an innovation during Henry II's reign, or if it is just mischance that the lone surviving Pipe roll prior to his reign does not record any scutage payments.<ref name=1066page717>Hollister "1066" ''American Historical Review'' p. 717</ref> The 1130 Pipe roll does allude to scutage payments, it just does not record any payment made.<ref name=Irony9>Hollister "Irony of English Feudalism" ''Journal of British Studies'' p. 9</ref>}}
Although they recorded all income that came through the Exchequer, not all sources of income went through that office, so the Pipe rolls are not a complete record of royal income. They did include both regular income from the royal lands and judicial profits, as well as more occasional income derived from feudal levies, [[Ward (law)|wardships]], and ecclesiastical vacancies.<ref name=Mortimer42>Mortimer ''Angevin England'' p. 42</ref> Another source of income recorded in the rolls was from feudal reliefs, the payment made by an heir when inheriting an estate.<ref name=Bartlett164>Bartlett ''England Under the Norman and Angevin Kings'' p. 164</ref><ref name=Coredon237>Coredon ''Dictionary of Medieval Terms'' pp. 237–238</ref> A major source of income in the roll of 1130 is from the forests, under the [[Royal forest#Forest law|Forest Law]],<ref name=Bartlett170>Bartlett ''England Under the Norman and Angevin Kings'' p. 170</ref> which was the royal law covering the restrictions imposed on non-royals hunting in areas of the country declared [[royal forest]].<ref name=Bartlett239>Bartlett ''England Under the Norman and Angevin Kings'' pp. 239–240</ref> However, royal income from taxation that was not annually assessed was not usually recorded in the Pipe rolls, nor were his receipts from lands outside England. Some payments went directly to the king's household, and because they did not pass through the Exchequer, they were not recorded in the Pipe rolls.<ref name=Bartlett159/>
Expenditures were also subject to documentation in the Pipe rolls. Among the recorded expenditures are payments for carts and cart horses,<ref name=Bartlett133>Bartlett ''England Under the Norman and Angevin Kings'' p. 133</ref> wages for royal servants, payments for improvements to royal manors and houses, royal gifts to persons,<ref name=Bartlett171>Bartlett ''England Under the Norman and Angevin Kings'' pp. 171–174</ref> hunting expenses,<ref name=Bartlett239/> payments to acquire a governmental office,<ref name=Huscroft159>Huscroft ''Ruling England'' p. 159</ref> payments to mercenaries,<ref name=Bartlett254>Bartlett ''England Under the Norman and Angevin Kings'' p. 254</ref> and the costs of bags and casks to transport [[Penny (English coin)|silver pennies]] about the kingdom.<ref name=Bartlett373>Bartlett ''England Under the Norman and Angevin Kings'' p. 373</ref>
Information about other subjects besides revenues also is contained in the rolls, including the movement of prisoners, which helps to identify which medieval castles were used as prisons.<ref name=Heiser20>Heiser "Castles, Constables and Politics" ''Albion'' p. 20 footnote 8</ref> The Pipe rolls also allow the identification of the custodians of royal lands and castles.<ref name=Heiser22>Heiser "Castles, Constables and Politics" ''Albion'' p. 22 footnote 22</ref> The clerks writing the rolls also used them as places to deride officials of the government, such as [[William Longchamp]], who was the object of derision in the 1194 Pipe roll.<ref name=Heiser32>Heiser "Castles, Constables and Politics" ''Albion'' p. 32</ref>
Certain areas did not report their income to the Exchequer, so they do not usually appear in the Pipe rolls, unless the lands were in the king's custody through a vacancy. These included the [[County palatine|palatinate]]s of [[County Durham|Durham]] and [[Cheshire|Chester]].<ref name=Palatinate719>Alexander "New Evidence" ''English Historical Review'' p. 719</ref> The county of [[Cornwall]] also did not usually appear in the Pipe rolls, but it was not a palatinate.<ref name=Palatinate724>Alexander "New Evidence" ''English Historical Review'' p. 724 and footnote 2</ref> Another problem with using the Pipe rolls for historical study is the fact that the chronological limits for the financial year varied from roll to roll.<ref name=Barratt636>Barratt "English Revenue of Richard I" ''English Historical Review'' p. 636</ref> In theory, they only recorded revenues from the previous [[Easter]] to Michaelmas of that financial year. However, the Pipe rolls often record payments made past Michaelmas, often up until the date the roll was actually compiled. Also, a few debts were not audited annually, but would instead have a number of consecutive years be investigated in one sitting and thus several years of payments would be recorded in one Pipe roll.<ref name=John836/>
==History== [[File:National Archives 2007 02 03.JPG|thumb|left|Entrance to [[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|The National Archives]], where the Pipe rolls are now held]]
Although the earliest Pipe roll dates from 1130, the 31st year of King Henry I's reign, it is clear that they were being produced by the Exchequer before then, as the 1130 roll is not an experiment. It shows no hesitancy in its use of accounts, or lack of continuity from previous years.<ref name=Chrimes30>Chrimes ''Administrative History'' pp. 30–31</ref> An extract from an earlier Pipe roll, from the 25th regnal year of Henry I or 1124, has been found in a 14th-century manuscript now in the [[Cotton Library]] at the [[British Museum]].<ref name=Hagger>Hagger "Pipe Roll for 25 Henry I" ''English Historical Review''</ref>{{efn|The extract is very short, but it shows that the Pipe rolls already recorded exemptions from [[danegeld]]. It is currently [[manuscript Tiberius]] E.vi part i.<ref name=Hagger/>}} Exactly when the Pipe rolls began to be produced is debated amongst historians. Some hold that they date from Henry I's reign, whether early or late in the reign,<ref name=Chrimes30/> but others feel that they were introduced by King [[William I of England|William I]] (reigned 1066–1087).<ref name=Clanchy151/> The precursors of the records probably date to the Anglo-Saxon period, as the historian [[Pauline Stafford]] argues that financial records must have been kept in some form during the reigns of [[Cnut the Great|Cnut]] (reigned 1016–1035), [[Ethelred the Unready|Æthelred II]] (reigned 978–1016), and [[Edgar the Peaceful|Edgar the Peaceable]] (reigned 959–975).<ref name=Stafford149>Stafford ''Unification and Conquest'' p. 149</ref> There is a reference to the king's "rolls" in a [[writ]] from 1110, which purports to be a grant from Henry I to the abbot of [[Westminster Abbey|Westminster]] of ten [[Shilling (British coin)|shillings]], but the writ may be a forgery, or parts of it may be genuine with some interpolations. As the writ only exists in a copy in a later [[cartulary]], and the Abbey of Westminster is also known to have forged a number of other writs or charters, the writ is not a solid source for royal rolls being kept as early as 1110.<ref name=Clanchy137>Clanchy ''From Memory to Written Record'' pp. 137–138</ref>
After the one surviving roll from Henry I's reign, no further Pipe rolls survived from his reign, nor are any preserved from the reign of his successor, King [[Stephen of England|Stephen]] (reigned 1135–1154). But by the second year of King Henry II's reign, or 1155, they once more survive.<ref name=Lyon112/> It is unclear if Pipe rolls were actually created during Stephen's reign and they did not survive, or if the conditions during Stephen's reign precluded the creation of Pipe rolls.<ref name=RandS257>Richardson and Sayles ''Governance'' p. 257 footnote 5</ref><ref name=Yoshi>Yoshitake "Exchequer in the Reign of Stephen" ''English Historical Review'' pp. 950–959</ref> Continuously from the early years of King Henry II's reign, most Pipe rolls survive, with only a break in the last years of King John's reign (reigned 1199–1216).<ref name=Mortimer66>Mortimer ''Angevin England'' pp. 66–68</ref>{{efn|The 1213 roll does not exist, and the 1215 roll was compiled after John's death and is not contemporary with the actual financial investigation carried out in that year.<ref name=John836>Barratt "Revenue of King John" ''English Historical Review'' p. 836 footnote 1</ref>}}
The surviving Pipe roll from 1130 records an income of £24,500.<ref name=Bartlett159>Bartlett ''England Under the Norman and Angevin Kings'' p. 159</ref> This figure is dwarfed by the amount recorded on the Pipe roll that was actually owed to the king, which totals £68,850.<ref name=Huscroft102>Huscroft ''Ruling England'' p. 102</ref> The income that they record in the early years of Henry II is much smaller than that of the one surviving year for Henry I. Those early Pipe rolls of Henry I record an income about £10,000 to £15,000. By the end of Henry II's reign, royal income recorded in the Pipe rolls had risen to £20,000. The end of John's reign saw a recorded income of about £30,000, but Henry III's reign recorded only £8,000 in the early years, rising to £16,500 by 1225.<ref name=Mortimer51>Mortimer ''Angevin England'' p. 51</ref> Not only do the rolls from the early years of Henry II's reign show less income reaching the Exchequer than during Henry I's reign, those early rolls were haphazard and not as accurate and detailed as rolls dating from the later part of the reign. Nor are they as carefully produced as either the later rolls or the roll of 1130.<ref name=RandS260>Richardson and Sayles ''Governance'' p. 260</ref>
By the time of King John, the Pipe rolls were growing unwieldy, as too many fines and fees were being recorded, making the finding of information in the rolls difficult. Eventually, after some experimentation, by 1206 a system was settled on whereby the actual detailed receipts were recorded in a set of ''receipt rolls'' and only aggregates were entered in the Pipe rolls.<ref name=Chrimes73>Chrimes ''Administrative History'' pp. 73–74</ref> A further reform in 1236 resulted in debts being recorded in separate ''[[Estreat]] rolls'', and only the totals entered into the Pipe rolls.<ref name=Chrimes119>Chrimes ''Administrative History'' p. 119</ref> In 1284 the ''[[Statute of Rhuddlan|Statutes of Rhuddlan]]'' were issued, which further reformed the accounting systems, and further reduced the detail contained on the Pipe rolls.<ref name=Chrimes148>Chrimes ''Administrative History'' p. 148</ref> At this time, a large number of unrecoverable debts were also removed from the rolls, a process that had also been attempted in 1270. The attempt in 1270 had marked old debts with a "d" and stipulated that they were not to be re-entered into future Pipe rolls unless they were paid off. But this had not worked, and so in 1284 old debts were to be recorded on a separate roll. The statutes in 1284 also laid out a procedure where debtors whose documentation of payment of debt that hadn't been accepted in the past would have that documentation accepted, thus helping to clear out some of the backlogged debts on the books.<ref name=EdwardI242>Prestwich ''Edward I'' pp. 242–243</ref>
Yet more extraneous details were removed from the Pipe rolls under the ''Cowick Ordinance'' of June 1323,<ref name=Chrimes181>Chrimes ''Administrative History'' p. 181</ref> along with further ordinances in 1324 and 1326, all of which were done during the time that [[Walter de Stapledon]] held the office of Treasurer.<ref name=Plant59>Prestwich ''Plantagenet England'' p. 59</ref> Prior to this reform the rolls had become clogged with debts, and clauses 2 through 8 of the ''Cowick Ordinance'' attempted to return the rolls to an exposition of accounts.<ref name=Buck246>Buck "Reform of the Exchequer" ''English Historical Review'' p. 246</ref> Another attempted reform at this time was the removal of [[customs]] receipts, as well as military accounts, from the rolls.<ref name=Graves473>Graves ''Bibliography of English History'' p. 473</ref> New offices in the Exchequer were also created, in an attempt to speed up the auditing process and lessen the time it took to prepare the Pipe rolls and other financial records.<ref name=Plant208>Prestwich ''Plantagenet England'' p. 208</ref> The attempt to remove non-Exchequer accounts did completely remove those types of records from the Pipe rolls, and further reforms in 1368 created a set of foreign rolls, and all extraneous records in the Pipe rolls were transferred to those rolls.<ref name=Graves473/>
In 1462, the exchequer was told to no longer summon for audit any farms or feefarms worth over 40 shillings per year, as these would be supervised by a newly appointed board of receivers or approvers.<ref name=Wolffe2>Wolfee "Management of English Royal Estates" ''English Historical Review'' p. 2</ref>
The Pipe rolls series ended in 1834 when the office that was in charge of their creation, the Pipe Office, was abolished.<ref name=Web>"[http://www.websters-online-dictionary.org/Pi/Pipe_Rolls.html Pipe rolls entry] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091231225308/http://www.websters-online-dictionary.org/Pi/Pipe_Rolls.html |date=31 December 2009 }}" ''Websters Online Dictionary''</ref>
==Creation== They were created by taking the shire, or other governmental districts, accounts and writing them on two strips of parchment, usually about {{convert|14|in|cm|sigfig=2}} wide.<ref name=Lyon112/> The two pieces were then attached end to end to form one long sheet. Then, the various sheets from all the shires were piled together and affixed together at the top, and the resulting document would be rolled into a tight roll resembling a pipe.<ref name=Coredon219/> They were not formed into one long continuous roll, as the [[Patent Rolls]] were, however. The sheets for each county have a heading at the top giving the name of the county the account is for, in Latin. If more than one sheet was required for a county, the county name would be amended on secondary sheets to indicate the order the sheets were in.<ref name=Ramsay>Ramsay "Origin of the Name Pipe Roll" ''English Historical Review'' pp. 329–220</ref>
Sometimes they are referred to, in [[Latin]], as ''magnus rotulus pipae''.<ref name=Chrimes50>Chrimes ''Administrative History'' p. 50</ref> Several sources for the actual idea of making the rolls as rolls have been suggested, including Jews, [[Adelard of Bath]], who was a royal clerk and was familiar with Arabic practices of using rolls, or the royal clerk Thurkil, who studied under a mathematician who may have been from Sicily.<ref name=Clanchy140>Clanchy ''From Memory to Written Record'' p. 140</ref>
The rolls were written in Latin until 1733, except for a short time around 1650.<ref name=NatArch>National Archives ''[http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/catalogue/RdLeaflet.asp?sLeafletID=186&j=1 Research Guides: Early Pipe Rolls, 1130–c. 1300]''</ref> During the reign of Henry II, a duplicate copy of the year's Pipe roll was made for the [[Lord Chancellor|Chancellor]], and was called the Chancellor's roll. This was created at the same time as the regular Pipe roll, and was written by a clerk of the Chancellor.<ref name=Lyon261>Lyon ''Constitutional and Legal History'' p. 261</ref> The Chancellor rolls survive from 1163 to 1832, but are basically duplicates of the corresponding Pipe rolls, except for the occasional addition of a private charter or other material.<ref name=Graves474/>
==Influence on other records== The example of the royal exchequer's records eventually influenced others to keep similar records. The earliest surviving non-royal Pipe rolls are those of the [[Bishop of Winchester]], which are extant from 1208,<ref name=Clanchy92/> and form a continuous series from that date. They started under [[Peter des Roches]], who was also a royal clerk and administrator.<ref name=Bartlett201>Bartlett ''England Under the Norman and Angevin Kings'' p. 201</ref> They record monies coming in as well as expenses and payments made, in detail, but like the royal records, they do not show profits or losses as a sum total. Most private rolls resembling the Pipe rolls are from monasteries. The household rolls, which closely resemble the Pipe rolls, for [[Eleanor of Leicester|Eleanor of England]], wife of [[Simon de Montfort, 6th Earl of Leicester|Simon de Montfort]], survive for part of the year 1265.<ref name=Clanchy92>Clanchy ''Memory to Written Record'' pp. 92–93</ref>
==Studies by historians==
A number of historians have studied the surviving Pipe rolls, using them as the basis for study of financial and governmental history, especially of the medieval era.<ref name=Mason148/><ref name=Mason157/><ref name=Mason162/> A study from 1925 compiled the royal income that passed through the Exchequer for each year of Henry II and Richard I, as well as a sample of some years from John's reign, attempting to compare how the royal revenues compared in the various reigns.<ref name=Bartlett175>Bartlett ''England Under the Norman and Angevin Kings'' pp. 175–176</ref> Recent work by [[Nick Barratt]] on the reigns of Richard and John have updated the earlier research.<ref name=Barratt>Barratt "English Revenue of Richard I" ''English Historical Review'' pp. 835–856</ref><ref name=John>Barratt "Revenue of King John" ''English Historical Review'' pp. 835–855</ref> Historian David Carpenter has carried out further studies on the early years of King Henry III's reign.<ref name=Bartlett175/> The Pipe rolls have also been used to identify royal officials, especially those that were involved in local government and were not high ranking.<ref name=Huscroft88>Huscroft ''Ruling England'' pp. 88–89</ref> Because they recorded judicial fines, the Pipe rolls also can be used to shed light on how the judicial system in medieval England worked, as well as identifying royal judges.<ref name=Lyon191>Lyon ''Constitutional and Legal History'' p. 191</ref><ref name=RandS176>Richardson and Sayles ''Governance'' pp. 176–177</ref> Although they don't provide exact revenue figures, most historians believe they represent a close approximation of revenue, and can be used to gain a general understanding of how much financial resources the English kings had available in the Middle Ages.<ref name=John836a>Barratt "Revenue of King John" ''English Historical Review'' pp. 836–837</ref>
The lone surviving Pipe roll from Henry I's reign, that of 1130, has been a popular subject of study. Recent investigations include [[Judith Green (historian)|Judith Green]]'s search for evidence of Henry's financial system. Another historian, Stephanie Mooers Christelow, has studied the roll along with those from the reign of Henry II, looking for the exemptions and grants made by both kings to various royal favourites.<ref name=Mason148>Mason "Administration and Government" ''Companion to the Anglo-Norman World'' pp. 148–149</ref> Christelow has also studied the 1130 roll to see what light it can shine on Henry I's judicial system, as well as on the growth of royal courts during Henry's reign.<ref name=Mason157>Mason "Administration and Government" ''Companion to the Anglo-Norman World'' p. 157</ref> The historian [[C. Warren Hollister]] used the 1130 Pipe roll to study the rewards of royal service during Henry's reign.<ref name=Mason162>Mason "Administration and Government" ''Companion to the Anglo-Norman World'' p. 162</ref>
The Pipe rolls from the 13th century onwards are less important for historical study because there are other surviving financial records. Some, such as the receipt rolls, were also kept by the exchequer, and were used by the treasury clerks to prepare the Pipe rolls. Other surviving records were kept by the sheriffs for their own use in submitting accounts to the Pipe rolls.<ref name=Lyon330>Lyon ''Constitutional and Legal History'' pp. 330–331</ref> However the post 13th-century Pipe rolls are occasionally the sole source for historical facts such as [[William Shakespeare]]'s residence in the parish of [[St Helen's Bishopsgate]], and in [[Southwark]].<ref name=Hales401>Hales "London Residences of Shakespeare" ''Athenaeum'' pp. 401-402</ref>
==Publication== [[File:Pipe roll 1174 record type.jpg|thumb|260px|right|Extract from the Pipe roll for [[Regnal years of English monarchs|21]] [[Henry II of England|Henry II]] (1174–5), as published by the Pipe Roll Society in 1897 using [[record type]].]]
The earliest Pipe rolls were published by the [[Record Commission]] in 1833 (the isolated roll of 1130) and the [[Public Record Office]] in 1844 (the rolls for 1155–58).<ref name=Graves474/> The Commission's edition of the 1130 roll has now been superseded by a new edition (with English translation) published by the Pipe Roll Society in 2012.<ref>Green ''Great Roll of the Pipe''</ref>
In 1883 the Pipe Roll Society (a [[text publication society]]) was founded by the Public Record Office, on the initiative of [[Walford Dakin Selby]] and his colleague James Greenstreet, to establish a systematic publishing programme for the Pipe rolls.<ref name=NatArch/> It published its first volume in 1884, and has now published all the rolls from 1158 to 1224.<ref name="PRS pubs">Pipe Roll Society "[http://www.piperollsociety.co.uk/page2.htm Pipe Roll Society Publications]"</ref><ref name="RHS PRS">{{cite web |author=Royal Historical Society |publisher=Royal Historical Society |url=http://5hm1h4aktue2uejbs1hsqt31.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/piperollsociety.pdf |title=Pipe Roll Society Publications |accessdate=11 December 2017 }}</ref> Besides the continuous series, it has also published the roll for 1230. The rolls for 1241 were published in 1918 by the [[Yale University Press]].<ref name=Graves474>Graves ''Bibliography of English History'', p. 474.</ref> Various county record societies have published parts of the rolls for various years that relate to their particular county. The Society's earliest volumes (to 1900) were printed in "[[record type]]", designed to produce a near-[[facsimile]] of the original manuscript, including its [[scribal abbreviation]]s. This policy was abandoned in 1903, and all volumes since have been published in normal type with abbreviations extended.<ref name=Pipe1904>Pipe Roll Society ''Great Roll of the Pipe'' pp. vii-viii</ref>
The Pipe Roll Society has also published numerous related texts, including the Chancellor's Roll for 1196 and the Norman Pipe Rolls of Henry II.<ref name="PRS pubs"/><ref name="RHS PRS"/> Rolls for the Irish Exchequer and the Norman Exchequer have also been published.<ref name=Graves475>Graves ''Bibliography of English History'' pp. 475–477.</ref>

C. |title=Texts and Calendars II: An Analytical Guide to Serial Publications 1957–1982 |year=1983 |publisher=Royal Historical Society| series=Royal Historical Society Guides and Handbooks No. 12 |location=London |isbn=0-86193-100-9 }} * {{cite web |author=[[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|National Archives]]|title= Research Guides: Early Pipe Rolls, 1130–c. 1300 |url= http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/catalogue/RdLeaflet.asp?sLeafletID=186&j=1 |publisher=[[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|The National Archives]] |work= www.nationalarchives.gov.uk}} Retrieved on 17 January 2009 * {{cite web |author=Pipe Roll Society |title= Pipe Roll Society Publications |url= http://www.piperollsociety.co.uk/page2.htm |publisher=Pipe Roll Society |work=www.piperollsociety.co.uk |accessdate=24 August 2014}} * {{cite book |author=Pipe Roll Society |title=The Great Roll of the Pipe for the Twenty-Second Year of the Reign of King Henry the Second: A.D. 1175–1176 |series=Pipe Roll Society |volume=25 |place=London |year=1904 |oclc= 25039201 }} * {{cite book |author=Prestwich, Michael|authorlink=Michael Prestwich |title=Edward I |publisher=Yale University Press |location=New Haven, CT |year=1997 |isbn=0-300-07157-4 }} * {{cite book |author=Prestwich, Michael |authorlink= Michael Prestwich |title= Plantagenet England 1225–1360 |year=2005 |publisher= Oxford University Press |location= Oxford, UK |isbn=978-0-19-922687-0 }} * {{cite journal |author=Ramsay, J. H. |title=The Origin of the Name Pipe Roll |journal =[[The English Historical Review]] |date=April 1911 |volume=26 |issue=102 |pages=329–330 |doi=10.1093/ehr/XXVI.CII.329 |jstor= 550492}} * {{cite book |author1=Richardson, H. G. |author2=Sayles, G. O. |author2link=G. O. Sayles |title= The Governance of Mediaeval England: From the Conquest to Magna Carta |year= 1963|publisher= Edinburgh University Press |location= Edinburgh |oclc= 504298 }} * {{cite web |author=Royal Historical Society |publisher=Royal Historical Society |url=http://5hm1h4aktue2uejbs1hsqt31.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/piperollsociety.pdf |title=Pipe Roll Society Publications |accessdate=21 March 2016 }} * {{cite book |author=Stafford, Pauline |authorlink=Pauline Stafford |title= Unification and Conquest: A Political and Social History of England in the Tenth and Eleventh Centuries |publisher=Edward Arnold |location=London |year=1989 |isbn=0-7131-6532-4 }} * {{cite book |author=Warren, W. P. |title=The Management of English Royal Estates under the Yorkist Kings |journal=[[The English Historical Review]] |date=January 1956 |volume=71 |issue=268 |pages=1–27 |doi=10.1093/ehr/LXXI.CCLXXVIII.1 |jstor= 558623}} * {{cite journal |author=Yoshitake, Kenji |title=The Exchequer in the Reign of Stephen |journal=[[The English Historical Review]] |volume=103 |issue=409 |date=October 1988 |pages=950–959 |doi=10.1093/ehr/CIII.CCCCIX.950 |jstor= 570263}} {{refend}}
==Further reading== {{refbegin|60em}} * {{cite journal |last=Amt |first=Emilie M. |title=The Meaning of Waste in the Early Pipe Rolls of Henry II |journal=[[Economic History Society|Economic History 10.1111/j.1468-2281.1982.tb01140.x}} * {{cite journal |last=Green |first=Judith A. |authorlink= Judith Green (historian) |journal=Historical Research |title=Unity and Disunity in the Anglo-Norman |editor=Vincent, Nicholas |publisher=Boydell Press |location=Woodbridge, UK |isbn=978-1-84383-485-4 |year=2009 |pages=45–74}} * {{cite journal |last=Keefe |first=Thomas K. |title=King Henry II and the Earls: The Pipe Roll Evidence |journal=[[Albion (history journal)|Albion]] |volume=13 |issue=3 |pages=191–222 |date=Autumn 1981 |jstor=4048847 |doi= 10.2307/4048847}} * {{cite journal |last=Mooers |first=Stephanie L. |title=A Re-evaluation of Royal Justice under Henry I of England |journal=[[American Historical Review]] |volume=93 |issue=2 |pages=340–58 |date=April 1988 |jstor= 1859922 |doi=
